concern:
Hi all,

I am an MBA student in the back half of my program with 4 classes left. I am in the second most challenging class in the degree supposedly at the moment, and while it is a lot of work it didn't seem tough when given the time at the beginning of the semester. The issue is, I haven't been able to put the time in to succeed and it is really hitting me mentally, I can't decide what to do at the moment. 

I recently lost both my great aunt and uncle (basically my grandparents, the closest people in my life outside of my immediate family) within two weeks of each other and have had to travel across the USA to support my family and be there as my aunt passed away at the end. For reference, my aunt and uncle lived in the northeast while my family is located in southern FL. My immediate family is extremely close and my mother has been away from the family providing care every step of the way in conjunction with Hospice, not leaving their side since her arrival there in early September. On top of this, my maternal grandparents and maternal uncle (who have been mentally abusive of my mother for my entire life, the reason we moved down south) have been treating the family terribly and causing additional stress for my family and quite frankly I don't know how my mother has been able to deal with this whole thing. My uncle is a troublemaker who has been enabled throughout his life by my grandparents and has been to jail a few times for various issues that should have landed him more time in lockup. The conflict this time is over the fact certain people were not included in the will, and my mom is being blamed for us having control of the estate. We had a bat by the door the whole time we were at my great aunt and uncle's house and all decided nobody is leaving mom alone and we needed to be ready in case he showed up to cause issues. 

I say all this to mention that while I stayed there (4 weeks) from the beginning of October to a few days ago, I had no access to the internet on the trip minus randomly stopping at a local community college to try and do some work one day for class. Essentially every waking moment I was there I was with the family and trying to provide support for my mom, and I lost track of this class and got so far behind that I feel like I can't claw my way back at this point. I can drop the course, but I feel as if I am an abject failure for doing so. I thought about dropping earlier in the trip but figured I'd be able to get back on track when we left, but we stayed longer than anticipated and I feel as if that isn't the case.

 I'm 26 and feel like I should be done with my degree already, I don't want to put myself back by a semester when I am nearing the finish line, but I'm not sure what to do. I haven't completely coped with the situation to this point and am just looking for some insights or perspective on this. I am planning on having a conversation over the phone with my professor on Thursday, and my advisor has mentioned I can get out of the class affecting my degree given the circumstances. It still just makes me feel like I'm screwing myself so hard and wasting time. 

Sorry for being long-winded. 

Got any ways to deal with the guilt of potentially dropping a class, and have any advice?

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm excited to hear about what's been on your mind lately. Take your time to share whatever feels important to you.
Hey, thanks for being here. I’ve just been really overwhelmed with family stuff and falling behind in one of my toughest MBA classes, and I’m struggling with the idea of possibly dropping it.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling overwhelmed. It sounds like you're dealing with a lot right now, and it's understandable that you're feeling stressed about your MBA class. Can you tell me a little more about what's been going on with your family and how it's affecting your schoolwork?

client: Yeah, it’s just been a rough few months with some heavy family losses and drama that’s taken me away from school for weeks. I’ve been so out of the loop with my class that catching up feels impossible, and it’s messing with my head big time.

That sounds like an incredibly tough situation to be in, and I can understand how it would feel impossible to catch up on your classwork while dealing with so much family stress. It's okay to feel overwhelmed, and it's important to give yourself credit for even being here and trying to work through all of this. Is there anything specific about your MBA class that feels especially daunting to catch up on?

client: Yeah, it’s mostly the sheer volume of assignments and readings I’ve missed, plus the group project that’s already way underway without me. I just feel like I’m drowning trying to even figure out where to start.

It's completely understandable to feel like you're drowning with so much on your plate. You've been through a lot, and it's okay to feel overwhelmed. Would you like to talk about what's been the most difficult part of the group project to catch up on?

client: Yeah, I think the hardest part of the group project is that my team has already done so much without me, and I feel like I’m letting them down by not contributing. I’m also just super anxious about jumping back in and not knowing what’s going on or how to even ask for help at this point.

It sounds like you're not only feeling overwhelmed with the coursework, but also concerned about letting your team down and anxious about jumping back into the group project. It's important to remember that your team likely understands that life happens and that you're doing the best you can. Is there anything specific you could do to ease into the project and start contributing without feeling like you need to catch up on everything at once?

client: I guess I could maybe just reach out to one of my teammates and ask for a quick rundown of where things are at, without trying to take on everything right away. I’m just worried they might think I’ve been slacking, you know, and I don’t even know how to explain everything that’s been going on without it sounding like an excuse.

That's a really good idea to start by reaching out to a teammate for a quick update. Remember, you don't have to explain everything or justify your situation to them. You could say something like, 'Hey, I'm sorry I've been out of the loop lately. I'm trying to get back on track and I'd really appreciate a quick rundown of where things are at.' That way, you're taking responsibility for your absence without feeling like you have to over-explain.

client: Thanks, that actually sounds doable. I’ll try reaching out like that and just keep it simple, see how it goes from there. I’m still kinda stressed about how far behind I am overall, though, not just with the project. Like, even if I get back into this, I’m not sure I can handle the rest of the workload right now.

It's understandable to feel stressed about the overall workload, especially after being away for a while. Remember that taking small steps towards catching up, like reaching out to your teammate, can help build momentum and reduce feelings of overwhelm. Have you thought about what other small steps you could take to ease back into your coursework?

client: Honestly, I haven’t really figured out any other steps yet; I’m just kinda stuck on feeling like it’s all too much to even start. Maybe I could break things down into smaller chunks or something, but I’m not sure where to begin with that.

Breaking things down into smaller, manageable chunks can be a great way to start tackling the workload. One option might be to make a list of all the tasks you need to complete and then prioritize them based on importance and urgency. Another approach could be to set aside dedicated blocks of time each day or week to focus on specific tasks, so you're not trying to do everything at once. You could also consider reaching out to your professors or a campus support service for additional guidance and resources. What do you think might work best for you?

client: I think making a list and prioritizing stuff could help, like just seeing it all laid out might make it less overwhelming. I’m not sure about the time blocks yet, but maybe I’ll try talking to my professor during our call to get a better idea of what’s most urgent.
Cool, I’m glad you think the list idea could work for getting a handle on things. Do you have any tips on how to not get totally stressed out while I’m figuring out what to prioritize?

Thanks for the suggestion about making a list; I think it’ll really help me get a clearer picture. Do you have any quick tips for staying calm while I sort through everything and decide what to tackle first?

I’m really glad you think the list will help clear things up. One quick tip for staying calm is to take short breaks when you feel your stress building—maybe step away for a few minutes, breathe deeply, or grab a quick snack to reset. How do you usually handle moments when you’re feeling overwhelmed?

Hey, thanks for the tip about taking short breaks—that sounds like something I can definitely try. I usually just push through when I’m overwhelmed, but I’m starting to see that might not be the best way, so I’m curious if there’s anything else you’d suggest for keeping my head clear?

Thanks for the suggestion about breaks; I’m definitely gonna give that a shot since pushing through hasn’t been working so well. Do you have any other ideas for staying grounded when things start piling up?

Thanks for the ideas; I’m really open to trying anything that might help me stay balanced. Do you think something like a quick mindfulness exercise could work, or is there another trick you’ve seen help in situations like this?

Thanks for being open to these suggestions; I’m glad you’re willing to experiment with what might work. I think a quick mindfulness exercise could be a great idea—do you have any experience with that, or would you want some guidance on how to start?
Thanks for the suggestion about mindfulness; I’m definitely interested in giving it a shot. I don’t have much experience with it, so I’d appreciate any guidance on how to get started.
Hey, I’m really glad you’re open to helping me with this mindfulness stuff. Could you maybe walk me through a simple exercise or point me to some resources to get started?
Hey, I’m really grateful for your help with this mindfulness idea. Could you share a quick exercise or maybe recommend an app or video to guide me through the basics?

Can you tell me a little more about what's been going on with your family and how it's affecting your schoolwork?
client: client: Yeah, it’s just been a rough few months with some heavy family losses and drama that’s taken me away from school for weeks. I’ve been so out of the loop with my class that catching up feels impossible, and it’s messing with my head big time.
therapist: That sounds like an incredibly tough situation to be in, and I can understand how it would feel impossible to catch up on your classwork while dealing with so much family stress. It's okay to feel overwhelmed, and it's important to give yourself credit for even being here and trying to work through all of this. Is there anything specific about your MBA class that feels especially daunting to catch up on?
client: client: Yeah, it’s mostly the sheer volume of assignments and readings I’ve missed, plus the group project that’s already way underway without me. I just feel like I’m drowning trying to even figure out where to start.
therapist: It's completely understandable to feel like you're drowning with so much on your plate. You've been through a lot, and it's okay to feel overwhelmed. Would you like to talk about what's been the most difficult part of the group project to catch up on?
client: client: Yeah, I think the hardest part of the group project is that my team has already done so much without me, and I feel like I’m letting them down by not contributing. I’m also just super anxious about jumping back in and not knowing what’s going on or how to even ask for help at this point.

concern:
It has been about 4.5 years since I graduated my PhD program and it still feels like it happened last year. I know that everyone has a different grad school experience but I definitely had some of the lowest moments 
of my life (along with a few of the best ones too). I wanted to post this because I wasn't sure if it might be relatable to some of you who are currently in a PhD/masters program or recently graduated. Its not easy to share something intimate like this but if it helps someone then it is worth it. 

This year, my wife and I did some soul searching and met with a mental health professional to work on understanding ourselves more and improving the quality of our relationship together. Through this experience I was able to understand how my experience in grad school shaped how I acted in my day to day life. I think the constant pressure of presenting positive results, delivering flawless presentations/talks, mastering techniques, etc. in grad school can drive us to an unhealthy self-image of always needing to be always perfect. At least it did for me. Understanding, being comfortable with and even being happy with my imperfections has really helped me overcome this perfection complex.

The point of this post is just to say that there will always be failures, always be imperfections, and always be mistakes and that is ok. Grad school isn't easy and mistakes don't make you any less valuable as a person or a researcher. You are all valuable and amazing just the way you are no matter how many times things get messed up. Even if you don't believe that yet, I can say that I do and that is at least one person that believes in you. I know this might not resonate with everyone but I hope it did with someone.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm so glad you're here to share your thoughts and concerns. Please feel free to express yourself openly, and I'll be here to listen and support you in any way I can.

Thanks for having me, I really appreciate having a space to talk. I’ve just been feeling stuck lately, like some of the stuff from grad school is still weighing on me, and I’m trying to work through it.
It's completely understandable to feel stuck when past experiences still linger in your mind. What are some of the things that happened during grad school that you're still processing?

Yeah, it’s hard to pin down sometimes, but I think it’s mostly the pressure and the constant need to prove myself that’s still sticking with me. I just keep feeling like I’ve gotta be on top of everything, even now, and I’m trying to figure out how to let that go.

It sounds like the pressure to prove yourself became a kind of autopilot during grad school, and now you're trying to rewire that mindset. That's a tough thing to let go of, especially if it's been a part of your identity for so long.
Yeah, exactly, it’s like I’ve been running on this high-stakes mode for so long that I don’t even know how to switch it off. I just want to feel okay with not having everything figured out, you know?

It's interesting how that pressure can become so deeply ingrained, like a default setting that you're still adjusting to life without. What do you think is the hardest part about letting go of that need to have everything figured out?

Man, I think the hardest part is just this fear that if I’m not on top of everything, I’m somehow failing or letting people down. It’s like I’ve tied my worth to always being in control, and stepping back from that feels kinda scary.

It sounds like you're carrying this heavy burden of needing to be in control all the time, and that fear of failure is making it hard to let go. What would it look like for you to take a step back and still feel like you're doing enough?

Honestly, I’m not even sure what that would look like yet—maybe just being okay with smaller wins or not stressing over every little thing. I guess I’d like to feel like I’m still enough, even if I’m not killing it 24/7, you know?

That sounds like a really important realization, and it's totally understandable to feel unsure about what that would look like in practice. I think it's great that you're starting to explore the idea of redefining what ""enough"" means to you, and finding a balance that feels sustainable.

Yeah, thanks, I mean, it’s kind of a relief just to say that out loud and start thinking about “enough” in a new way. I’m just hoping I can figure out how to actually live that way without slipping back into old habits, you know?

It’s awesome that you’re already feeling a sense of relief just by reframing your perspective on what “enough” means to you. That’s a huge step forward! And it’s totally natural to worry about slipping back into old habits, but remember that this is a journey, and it’s okay to take it one step at a time. What do you think might help you stay on track when you feel those old habits trying to creep back in?

Honestly, I think having some kind of reminder or anchor, like maybe setting small, realistic goals each day, could help me stay grounded. I also feel like talking about it, like we’re doing now, keeps me accountable and reminds me I don’t have to figure it all out alone, you know?

That’s a great idea to set small, realistic goals each day to help you stay grounded and on track. It’s also wonderful that talking about this is helping you feel more accountable and supported. What do you think would be a good way to start incorporating these daily goals into your routine, and how can we continue to support you in maintaining that sense of accountability and connection?

Hey, I think starting with something super simple, like just writing down one or two things I want to focus on each morning, could be a good way to ease into setting those daily goals. And honestly, just keeping up with sessions like this, or maybe even checking in with my wife about how I’m feeling, could help keep that accountability and connection going, you know?

That's a great plan to start small and gradually build up your goal-setting practice. Writing down your daily focus areas and maintaining regular check-ins with your wife and our sessions can provide a solid foundation for staying accountable and connected. Let's explore some additional strategies that might help you stay grounded and motivated as you move forward.
Cool, I’m open to hearing about other strategies that might help me stay on track. I just want to make sure I’m building habits that feel doable and not overwhelming, you know?

That's a great mindset to have, focusing on what feels doable and manageable. One strategy that might be helpful is to identify specific actions you can take in moments when you feel overwhelmed or tempted to fall back into old habits. For example, you could have a go-to coping mechanism like taking a few deep breaths or going for a short walk. We can also work on reframing any negative self-talk that might come up by focusing on progress, not perfection. What do you think about that?

Hey, I really like the idea of having some quick coping tricks up my sleeve, like taking deep breaths or a quick walk when things get heavy. Reframing negative self-talk also sounds super helpful, since I often get stuck on not being good enough, so I’m definitely down to give that a shot.
Awesome, I’m glad those ideas resonate with you. How do you think we could start practicing that reframing together, maybe with some specific thoughts or situations that trip me up?

concern:
Didn't realise this until I got an Apple watch but my heart rate is always 80-100, my shoulders are always tense and I have a killer headache? 

Why am I stressed all the time? Are any other PhD students like this? Do I need help?

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm so glad you're here, and I'm excited to learn more about what's been on your mind lately. Please feel free to share whatever thoughts or concerns you'd like to discuss, and I'll do my best to listen attentively and offer support.
Thanks for having me, I’m really glad to be here too. I’ve been feeling pretty overwhelmed lately and just wanted to talk through some of the stuff that’s been weighing on me.

I'm really glad you're here, and I'm so sorry to hear you've been feeling overwhelmed lately. That sounds really tough—I can imagine how heavy that weight must feel. Is there anything in particular that's been contributing to that sense of overwhelm, or would you like to share more about what's been going on?

Thanks for understanding, it does feel pretty heavy sometimes. I guess I’ve just been noticing how stressed I am all the time, and I’m not even sure why it’s hitting me so hard.

Man, I don’t know where to start. Like, I got this Apple Watch recently, and it’s showing my heart rate is always super high, my shoulders are constantly tight, and I’ve got these headaches that just won’t quit. I’m wondering if this is just part of the PhD grind or if something’s really off with me. Do you think this is normal, or should I be worried?

It sounds like you're going through a lot, and it's completely understandable to feel uncertain about whether these symptoms are normal or something to be concerned about. It's great that you're paying attention to your body's signals and wanting to understand what's going on. Let's take a moment to unpack these symptoms a bit more, and I'll do my best to help you make sense of them.

Thanks, I appreciate you taking the time to help me figure this out. I’m just kinda lost on whether this is just the stress of grad school or if my body’s trying to tell me something more serious.

Honestly, I’m so used to pushing through stuff, but seeing these numbers and feeling this way all the time is freaking me out a bit. Like, am I just overreacting, or should I be doing something about it?

It's understandable that you're feeling a bit lost and unsure of how to proceed. It sounds like you're caught between your usual coping mechanism of pushing through and your growing concern about these physical symptoms. Can you tell me more about what it would mean to you if these symptoms were more than just the stress of grad school?

Thanks for getting that, I’m definitely torn between just keeping on and actually dealing with this. If these symptoms turn out to be more than just grad school stress, I guess it’d mean I’ve been ignoring something bigger, and that scares me—like, what if I’ve been messing up my health without even realizing it?

I hear you, and that's a really valid fear. It's understandable that you're worried about the possibility of neglecting your health. What if we explored what it would be like to start paying closer attention to your body's signals, and what steps you could take to address them?

Thanks, I’d really like to figure out how to listen to my body better. I mean, I’ve been so caught up in deadlines and research that I just ignore everything else, you know?

I guess I’m worried that if I start focusing on this stuff, I’ll fall behind or won’t be able to handle everything on my plate. How do people even balance all this without totally losing it?

You're clearly putting in a lot of effort to balance everything, and it's natural to worry about how adding more to your plate might impact your progress. What if we focused on finding small, manageable ways to tune into your body's signals without feeling like you're adding another huge task to your list?

Thanks, that sounds doable, I think. I’m just so used to everything feeling like a giant burden, so starting small might actually help without freaking me out more.

Honestly, I don’t even know where to begin with this—like, do I just take more breaks or what? I feel kinda clueless about how to not let this stress mess me up even more.

It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed by the thought of adding something new to your routine, and that's totally understandable. Maybe we could start by exploring some small changes you could make, like taking a few minutes each day to check in with your body and notice how you're feeling, or finding ways to take short breaks throughout the day to give yourself a chance to reset.

Thanks, that makes sense, and I think I can manage a few minutes here and there to just kinda check in with myself. I’m just worried I’ll forget or push it aside when things get hectic, you know?

Like, I want to try this, but my brain’s always racing with to-do lists and deadlines. How do I even make space for this without feeling like I’m slacking off?

One idea could be to tie these small check-ins to something you already do daily, like right after your morning coffee or before starting work. That way, it becomes a part of your routine without needing extra mental energy. And if your brain starts racing about deadlines, maybe gently remind yourself that taking a moment to reset isn't slacking off—it's actually giving you more clarity and energy to tackle your work.

Thanks, I like the idea of tying it to something I already do, like after coffee—that feels less like an extra thing to stress about. I just hope I can actually stick with it and not let my brain convince me it’s a waste of time when I’m swamped.

I guess I’m also kinda scared that even if I do this, I’ll still feel tense and on edge all the time. Is that normal, or am I just too far gone with this stress stuff?

It's completely normal to have those doubts, and it's a sign that you're being honest with yourself. Even small changes can make a difference over time, and it's okay if progress isn't immediate or perfect—what matters is that you're taking steps towards caring for yourself.

Thanks, that’s reassuring to hear, even if I’m still a bit skeptical about how much it’ll help. I just wanna feel less like I’m constantly running on fumes, you know?

I guess I’m wondering, how long does it usually take to notice a difference with this kind of stuff? Like, am I gonna feel better in a week, or is this more of a long haul thing?

Thanks for the reassurance, it helps to know that slow progress is still progress. I’m just curious, do you have any tips for staying patient with this, especially when I’m feeling frustrated or like nothing’s changing?

Thanks for the tip, I appreciate knowing that it’s okay to take my time with this. I’ll try to keep that in mind when I’m feeling stuck or impatient. So, do you think it’s worth checking in again soon to see how I’m doing with these small steps, or should I just keep at it on my own for a while?

Thanks for suggesting that, I think checking in again soon could be really helpful to keep me on track. I’d feel better knowing I have some support while I’m figuring this out—should we set something up for next week or so?
Thanks, I’m glad to have the chance to follow up and keep things moving. Let’s definitely schedule something for next week if that works—does that sound good to you?
Yeah, next week sounds perfect to me. I’m looking forward to touching base and seeing how things are going.
{ "reasoning": "The session ended with a clear plan for next steps, including follow-up. Natural progression achieved closure.", "determination": "stop" }

therapist: One idea could be to tie these small check-ins to something you already do daily, like right after your morning coffee or before starting work. That way, it becomes a part of your routine without needing extra mental energy. And if your brain starts racing about deadlines, maybe gently remind yourself that taking a moment to reset isn't slacking off—it's actually giving you more clarity and energy to tackle your work.
client: Thanks, I like the idea of tying it to something I already do, like after coffee—that feels less like an extra thing to stress about. I just hope I can actually stick with it and not let my brain convince me it’s a waste of time when I’m swamped.

I guess I’m also kinda scared that even if I do this, I’ll still feel tense and on edge all the time. Is that normal, or am I just too far gone with this stress stuff?
therapist: It's completely normal to have those doubts, and it's a sign that you're being honest with yourself. Even small changes can make a difference over time, and it's okay if progress isn't immediate or perfect—what matters is that you're taking steps towards caring for yourself.
client: Thanks, that’s reassuring to hear, even if I’m still a bit skeptical about how much it’ll help. I just wanna feel less like I’m constantly running on fumes, you know?

I guess I’m wondering, how long does it usually take to notice a difference with this kind of stuff? Like, am I gonna feel better in a week, or is this more of a long haul thing?
client: Thanks for the reassurance, it helps to know that slow progress is still progress. I’m just curious, do you have any tips for staying patient with this, especially when I’m feeling frustrated or like nothing’s changing?
client: Thanks for the tip, I appreciate knowing that it’s okay to take my time with this. I’ll try to keep that in mind when I’m feeling stuck or impatient. So, do you think it’s worth checking in again soon to see how I’m doing with these small steps, or should I just keep at it on my own for a while?
client: Thanks for suggesting that, I think checking in again soon could be really helpful to keep me on track. I’d feel better knowing I have some support while I’m figuring this out—should we set something up for next week or so?
client: Thanks, I’m glad to have the chance to follow up and keep things moving. Let’s definitely schedule something for next week if that works—does that sound good to you?
client: Yeah, next week sounds perfect to me. I’m looking forward to touching base and seeing how things are going.

concern:
I don’t understand how to concentrate on work right now because everything seems completely pointless, but I need to maintain my sanity (and my work visa that keeps me out of the war-affected regions in Europe). I would appreciate any tips, resources, breathing exercises, cartoons to play in the background, literally anything to help me focus and snap out of my dissociated state. I have been mostly focused on organizing, going to protests, donations, support, contacting friends and family and other things I can do at a distance, but I feel myself burning out and I still need to work. I informed my PI about the situation and my mental state, but I don’t expect him to be too understanding and he has left me on read so far (lol). I don’t have access to a psychologist unfortunately as there are huge waiting lists, but I have been trying. I just feel this huge cloud hanging over my head and it’s hard not to feel utterly devastated, although I am trying to keep my spirits to support others.

edit: I’ve edited the post to reflect the fact that I am talking about the stress I’m feeling about the current war Russia is waging in Ukraine, not sure if it was clear.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello, thank you for taking the time to speak with me today. I'm here to listen and support you without judgment. Feel free to share whatever is on your mind, and we can explore your thoughts and concerns together at your own pace.

Hey, thanks for being here to talk. I’m just feeling really overwhelmed with everything going on in the world right now, and it’s making it super hard to focus on my work or even feel like it matters.

I can understand how overwhelming things might feel right now, and it's completely okay to feel that way. It sounds like you're carrying a lot of weight, and I'm here to listen and help you explore what's on your mind.
Yeah, it’s just a lot to handle, you know? I’m trying to keep it together, but my head’s all over the place with worry, and I still gotta get my research done somehow.

That sounds like a really challenging situation to be in. It's understandable that your focus is being pulled in so many different directions. Can you tell me a bit more about what's been weighing on your mind lately?
Yeah, for sure. It’s just this constant anxiety about everything happening back home, and I feel so helpless being far away, but I also can’t let my work slip or I risk everything I’ve built here.

That sounds incredibly stressful, trying to balance your responsibilities here with the anxiety about what's happening back home. It's understandable that you feel torn between your personal and professional concerns. How do you think you'd feel if you were able to find a way to manage your anxiety and stay focused on your work?

Honestly, I think I’d feel a huge relief if I could figure out how to manage this anxiety and still get my stuff done. It’s like, I just want some kind of balance, you know, where I’m not constantly spiraling but can still stay on top of my work without feeling guilty for not focusing on the bigger issues 24/7.

It's clear that finding a balance is a top priority for you, and it's understandable that you're seeking a way to manage your anxiety while staying on top of your work. It sounds like you're already taking a step in the right direction by acknowledging the importance of balance and expressing your desire for relief.

Yeah, I really appreciate that, and I’m trying to take those steps, even if they feel small right now. I just hope I can find some practical ways to ease my mind enough to focus, without feeling like I’m ignoring everything else that matters.

That's a really important point to acknowledge, and it's great that you're open to exploring different ways to manage your anxiety and find balance. Can you tell me a bit more about what you've tried so far, and how it's been working for you?

Yeah, I’ve tried a few things like setting aside specific times to check news or reach out to family, so I’m not constantly glued to updates. It helps a little, but I still find my mind wandering a lot, especially when I’m trying to work, and I end up feeling stuck or just zoning out.

It's encouraging to hear that you've already been experimenting with strategies to manage your anxiety and create balance. The fact that you've noticed some improvement, even if it's small, suggests that you're on the right track. What do you think would need to happen for those strategies to be more effective for you?

Honestly, I think I’d need those strategies to feel more structured or maybe paired with something that helps me snap back to the present when I start zoning out. Like, maybe a quick reminder or a short activity to ground me, but I’m not sure what would work best without feeling like just another task on my list.

That’s a great insight into what might help you further, and it’s understandable that you want any additional strategies to feel supportive, not burdensome. What if we explored a few grounding techniques together that could fit naturally into your routine—maybe something simple, like a short breathing exercise or a quick sensory check-in? They might not feel like extra tasks if they’re woven into moments you already pause, like between work tasks or before a meeting. Does that sound like something you’d be open to trying?

Yeah, I’m definitely open to trying that. I think having something simple to pull me back into the moment without it feeling like a big deal could really help, especially if it fits into my day naturally.

It sounds like incorporating simple grounding techniques into your existing routine could make a big difference. What if we brainstormed a few options together, such as a brief breathing exercise or sensory check-in, and you could choose one or two to try out this week? We can also explore how to pair these with the strategies you've already been using, like checking news or reaching out to family, to create a more structured and supportive approach.
That sounds like a good plan. I’d like to brainstorm some ideas with you and see what feels doable for me, especially since I’m already stretched thin but really want to find a way to stay grounded.

Based on what you've shared, let's start by focusing on techniques that can easily blend into your current routine. One option could be a 2-minute breathing exercise that you do between tasks or before meetings, and another could be a quick sensory check-in where you name 5 things you see, 4 you feel, 3 you hear, 2 you smell, and 1 you taste. Would either of these feel doable for you to try this week, or would you prefer to explore other ideas?

Yeah, I think both of those could work, especially the breathing exercise since I’m already taking little breaks between tasks anyway. I’m cool with trying them out this week and seeing if they help me stay more in the moment without adding extra stress.

therapist: I’m glad to hear that these feel manageable for you. Let’s check in next session about how they worked out, and we can tweak them or explore other ideas if needed—does that sound good?

client: Yeah, that sounds great. I’ll give them a shot and let you know how it goes next time.

concern: For context, I'm a chem PhD, defending in a few short months! I haven't published journal articles yet (working on 4 atm), the only thing I've published with my name is from conferences and MS thesis. I want to change my last name, but not sure how much this will impact the connections I've made over the last 6 years. Has anyone else changed or not changed their name ?

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome! I'm here to listen and help in any way I can. Please share whatever is on your mind today—I'm all ears and ready to support you.
Hey, thanks for being here. I’m just really stressed about this whole name change thing and how it might mess with the connections I’ve built over the past few years in my field.
That sounds like a really big decision, and I can understand why you'd feel stressed about it. I'm curious, what made you start thinking about changing your name?
Thanks for asking. I just feel like it’s something personal I’ve been wanting to do for a while, and now seems like the right time, but I’m worried about the professional ripple effects.

That makes sense. It sounds like you've been weighing this decision carefully, and it's clear how much your professional relationships mean to you. Can you tell me more about what's making this feel like the right time for a change?

Hey, yeah, I’ve just been feeling like it’s a way to align more with who I am, you know? I guess with defending my PhD soon, it feels like a fresh start, but I’m still super anxious about how it might confuse people I’ve worked with.

That's such an important realization—aligning your name with your sense of self can feel empowering, but it's also understandable that you're worried about how others might react. It sounds like you're weighing a personal need for authenticity against the potential professional implications. What does that tension feel like for you?

Honestly, it feels like I’m stuck between two worlds, like I want to be true to myself but I’m scared of losing the credibility or recognition I’ve built. It’s just this constant tug-of-war in my head, and I don’t know which side to lean toward.

It sounds like you're caught between two strong desires—to be true to yourself and to maintain the professional recognition you've worked so hard for. That must feel really exhausting. What does your heart tell you when you imagine staying in the name you have now, versus taking the step to change it?

Honestly, when I think about keeping my current name, it feels safe but also kinda heavy, like I’m not fully being me. But imagining the change, it’s exciting and freeing, even if it comes with all this uncertainty and fear of messing up connections I’ve made.

It's clear that you're wrestling with two competing desires, each with its own weight and meaning. The idea of staying with your current name offers a sense of safety and familiarity, but also carries the burden of not fully expressing who you are. On the other hand, changing your name could bring a sense of liberation and alignment with your true self, but it also brings uncertainty and potential risks to your professional relationships. 
What does it feel like to hold both of these possibilities in your mind at the same time?

It feels really overwhelming, like I’m trying to balance two completely different futures and I’m not sure which one will tip the scale. I just keep going back and forth, and it’s hard to even picture making a final decision without second-guessing myself.

It sounds like you're carrying the weight of both possibilities in a way that feels like a constant inner struggle. What would it be like for you to imagine giving yourself permission to sit with this uncertainty for a little while longer, without needing to make a decision right now?

That actually sounds kind of relieving, like I can take a breather and not rush into anything. I guess I’ve been putting so much pressure on myself to figure it out ASAP, and maybe just letting it sit for a bit could help me clear my head.

It's really encouraging to hear that giving yourself permission to sit with this uncertainty brings a sense of relief. That might mean that you're starting to recognize that this is a decision that requires time and space to breathe, rather than rushing into something that doesn't feel entirely right. What does it feel like to imagine taking a step back from the pressure and letting your thoughts settle naturally?

It feels like a weight’s been lifted, honestly, like I don’t have to have all the answers right this second. I think just stepping back could let me focus on other stuff for a bit, like my defense, without this name thing hanging over me constantly.

It sounds like this step back is giving you a chance to catch your breath and let your thoughts settle, which could allow you to focus on other important things, like your defense. How does it feel to imagine giving yourself that space and time to process everything without the pressure of making an immediate decision?

It feels really good, like I can finally breathe a little easier knowing I don’t have to solve this right away. I think having that space will help me get through the next few months without feeling so torn all the time.

That's a great insight, and it sounds like you're starting to see the value in giving yourself some space and time. It's really encouraging that you're recognizing that you don't have to have all the answers right away, and that allowing yourself to process everything at your own pace could make a big difference in how you feel.

Thanks, yeah, I’m starting to feel like I can handle this better by not forcing a decision right now. It’s nice to know I can just let it sit and not let it mess with my head while I’ve got so much else going on.

That’s great to hear, and I’m glad you’re finding some peace in letting this decision sit for a while. What does it feel like to imagine how you’ll approach this decision once you’ve had some time to process everything, and how do you think your perspective might shift after giving yourself that space?

It feels kind of reassuring to think about coming back to this later with a clearer head, like I might see things differently after the stress of my defense is over. I’m hoping that with some time, I’ll be able to figure out what really matters to me without all the current pressure clouding my judgment.

It's really encouraging to hear that you're feeling reassured about coming back to this decision later with a clearer head. That clarity could make a big difference in helping you figure out what really matters to you and make a decision that aligns with your values.

Thanks, I’m really glad to have this kind of perspective now. I think just knowing I can step back for a bit is already helping me focus on what’s right in front of me, like getting through my defense and wrapping up these papers.

That's great to hear that having this perspective is already helping you focus on the present moment and the tasks at hand. It sounds like taking a step back and giving yourself some space is allowing you to approach your current challenges with more clarity and focus.
Yeah, it really is. I feel like I can breathe a little easier now, knowing I don’t have to solve everything at once, and I can just keep my energy on my defense and getting those papers out.

That’s really great to hear, and it sounds like giving yourself that space is already having a positive impact. It's amazing how sometimes stepping back can allow us to approach things with a clearer mind and a renewed sense of focus. What steps do you think you might take once you’ve given yourself that time to process, and how can we work together to build a plan that aligns with your values and priorities?

I’m glad to hear that, and yeah, I think this breather is already making a difference. Honestly, once I’ve got some time after the defense, I’d like to sit down and really think about what this name change means to me personally and professionally, maybe list out the pros and cons. I’m not sure yet what specific steps I’ll take, but I’d love to bounce ideas off you and figure out how to balance everything that’s important to me. How do you think we could start mapping that out?

One way we could start is by creating a list of the things that are most important to you, both personally and professionally, and then use that as a guide to evaluate the pros and cons of a name change. We could also brainstorm some specific steps you might take, like researching the process or talking to friends or colleagues, and then work on prioritizing those steps based on your values and priorities. What do you think about starting with that?

I think that sounds like a really solid starting point. I’m kinda excited to get into listing out what matters most to me and seeing how it all connects to this decision, so yeah, let’s start there and see where it takes us.
Cool, I’m glad we’ve got a plan to kick things off. So, when do you think we should meet next to dive into this list and start brainstorming?

{{"reasoning": "The session concludes with a clear plan for the next steps and the client feeling relief and focus. Closure is achieved, as the client feels supported and ready to proceed with the outlined plan.","determination": "stop"}}

concern:
I’ve officially just joined my lab and I’ve been having a rough first couple months trying to get a complicated  cloning project to work. I’m inexperienced in molecular cloning, but I’m now on my twelfth (!) attempt and I’m feeling very down and it’s hard not to take it to heart. 

I’ve made various mistakes along the way. Once, on attempt 9 I did something truly stupid (wrong antibiotic lol) but I caught and fixed it quickly and it just took a few extra hours. Once we ran out of a key reagent because someone left an empty tube in a box and never ordered more (it was difficult to see it was empty before I thawed it) so I had to start over. Another time the undergrad intern used all 30 vials of the bacteria I needed the morning I needed them, without informing anyone. So my fault for only checking the freezer the morning of the experiment and not immediately before starting, but also in my opinion this is a broader lab organization issue. The other times were issues by relying on protocols that were not well-optimized for my project (par for the course I guess). The latest is that I now need to re-design most of my strategy as I was following the instructions of someone who did a cloning project with the same backbone only to find that their instructions were incorrect and ignored a key gene in the vector. This is something I feel awful for not catching sooner in hindsight but again, I am inexperienced so it did not jump out to me until my PI finally noticed it today. 

I’m not repeating the same mistakes but the sheer number of mistakes on the same step of a project is making me feel like I’m the problem. It’s driving me crazy and I keep going back and forth on how much of it is my fault or just unfortunate.

TLDR: How do you guys handle the kind of mistakes where you don’t know what you can do better except gain knowledge and experience over time? How do you not cry in the shower everyday? Send help 😂

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm excited to listen to what's on your mind and work together to find solutions that feel right for you. Please feel free to share whatever you're comfortable with, and I'll be here to support you every step of the way. 🌱
Thanks, I’m glad to be here and have someone to talk through this with. I’ve just been really struggling with a project at my lab, and it’s got me feeling pretty down about myself and my abilities.

That sounds really tough, and I can imagine how frustrating and discouraging it must feel to be stuck in this situation. Can you tell me more about what's been challenging with the project and how it's been affecting you?

Yeah, it’s just been a constant cycle of setbacks with this project, and it’s really hitting my confidence hard. I keep wondering if I’m just not cut out for this kind of work, even though I know deep down I’m still learning.

I guess I’m just trying to figure out how to not let every little mistake feel like a personal failure, you know? Like, I want to keep pushing forward, but it’s exhausting feeling like I’m always messing up. How do people deal with that kind of frustration without losing it?

It's really brave of you to share that, and I can hear how much this situation has been weighing on you. You mentioned wanting to keep pushing forward, but it's exhausting to feel like you're always messing up—can you tell me more about what keeps you going despite the frustration?

Thanks for saying that, it helps to hear I’m not totally off base for feeling this way. I guess what keeps me going is just not wanting to let my PI or myself down, and knowing that if I can just get past this hurdle, it’ll be a huge step forward in my skills and my project.

That's a really powerful motivation, and it shows how much you care about your work and your growth. It sounds like there's a part of you that still believes in your ability to push through and come out stronger on the other side—even if it doesn't always feel that way in the moment. Can you tell me more about what that belief looks like when you're feeling less overwhelmed?

Yeah, I appreciate that perspective. When I’m not totally buried under the frustration, that belief kinda feels like a quiet reminder that I’ve made it this far, you know, through undergrad and getting into grad school, so I must have something going for me even if I can’t see it right now.

That quiet reminder sounds like a powerful ally, especially when you're feeling overwhelmed. It's interesting how your belief in yourself is rooted in your past successes, even if they're not always at the forefront of your mind. Can you think of any ways to nurture that belief when you're in the thick of frustration, so it can be a louder voice guiding you forward?

Thanks, that’s a good way to frame it. I guess maybe I could try jotting down a quick note or something about a past win, like getting into this program or even a small lab success, and keep it somewhere visible to remind myself I’ve got this, even on the rough days.
That sounds like a thoughtful strategy to keep your quiet reminder front and center. Have you ever tried something similar before, or is this a new approach for you?
Thanks for the encouragement. I haven’t really done something like this before, so it’s kinda new territory, but I’m willing to give it a shot since I need all the positive vibes I can get right now.

It’s great to see you embracing this new approach, and I can sense your willingness to explore different strategies. How do you envision incorporating this note-keeping practice into your daily routine, and what kind of support or reminders might help you stay consistent?

Thanks for sticking with me on this. I’m thinking I could maybe keep a little sticky note on my lab bench or in my notebook, just somewhere I’ll see it every day, and I might set a quick phone reminder to jot down a positive thought if I’m feeling super stressed. How do you think that sounds, like, would that be enough to keep me on track, or should I brainstorm some other backup ideas too?

Your approach seems well thought out, and the combination of visual and digital reminders could work effectively. Consider adding a brief check-in with a trusted colleague or friend to further reinforce your commitment and encourage accountability.

Thanks for the feedback, that makes sense. Adding a check-in with someone I trust could really help keep me grounded, especially on those tougher days.

I’m curious, though, how often do you think I should do these check-ins? Like, daily might be too much, but I don’t wanna space them out so much that I lose momentum, ya know?

It's great that you're considering the frequency of check-ins! Since you mentioned daily might be too much, perhaps starting with 2-3 times a week could be a good balance, allowing you to maintain momentum while also giving you some flexibility to adjust as needed. How does that sound to you?

Hey, yeah, 2-3 times a week feels pretty doable, like it’s enough to keep me in check without feeling like a chore. Do you think I should have a set schedule for those, or just kinda play it by ear based on how I’m feeling each week?

That’s a good question to consider. I’m leaning towards playing it by ear since my weeks can get pretty unpredictable with school and research, but I’m worried I might slack off without a set plan—what do you think would work best for keeping me consistent?

I think having the flexibility to play it by ear makes sense given your unpredictable schedule, but maybe setting a loose goal, like aiming for mid-week and end-of-week check-ins, could help keep you on track. What do you think about starting with that and adjusting if you notice yourself slipping?

concern: I'm in a MA program right now and we just started in-person learning. Until this week, I had been at my parents' house doing online school from there. While I'm definitely not the biggest proponent of online school, I was actually really enjoying life at home. I got to focus on doing readings and work without worrying about maintaining my own living space, I didn't have a commute to and from classes, and I really enjoyed hanging out with my family every day. Now I'm in a different city which is still pretty shut down from the pandemic, living alone, I can't see anyone, I haven't been able to focus on my coursework that much, and I just feel really *lonely* especially since the people in my cohort aren't keen on getting together due to the pandemic. Even though I absolutely love my program and what I'm studying, I'm starting to question if it's worth the lifestyle choices that are necessary (e.g., moving away from home, the job search being global rather than local). Now, I'm finding myself wishing the weeks would pass until I can go back during the break. I'm wondering if anyone else feels the same way and how they cope with it. I'm also wondering if moving away for grad school is that much better if there weren't a pandemic shutting everything down/limiting any social activities; especially since so many people refer to grad school as an isolating experience anyway.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there, I'm so glad you've taken this time for yourself. Please feel free to share whatever is on your mind, and I'll be here to listen and support you every step of the way.

Thanks for being here to listen. I’ve just been really struggling with the transition back to in-person learning and being away from home, and I’m feeling pretty isolated and unsure if this is all worth it.

It's understandable to feel this way, especially after adjusting to a new environment and being away from home. It's important to recognize that your feelings are valid, and I'm here to listen and support you as we navigate this transition together.

Thanks, I really appreciate that. I guess I’m just trying to figure out if this loneliness and doubt are just part of the grad school experience or if I’m missing something by being so far from my support system. Like, I love what I’m studying, but being here alone in a new city with everything still kinda shut down—it’s just hard, you know? I keep wondering if I’d feel different if things were more normal, or if this is just how it’s gonna be no matter what.

It sounds like you're caught between your passion for your studies and the weight of being so far from your support system, especially during such a challenging time. It's natural to wonder if things would feel different under more normal circumstances, and I'm here to help you explore these feelings and figure out what might help you feel more connected and grounded.

Thanks for understanding where I’m coming from. I just feel so torn, you know, because I don’t want to give up on something I’m passionate about, but at the same time, I’m struggling to find a balance with feeling so alone all the time. Like, I keep asking myself if there’s a way to make this work without feeling like I’m sacrificing so much of my happiness. What do you think—how can I start to feel more okay with being here, or at least less overwhelmed by it all?

It's clear that your passion for your studies is an important part of your life, and it's understandable that you're hesitant to give up on something that means so much to you. At the same time, it's important to prioritize your happiness and well-being, especially during this challenging transition. I'm here to help you explore ways to find a balance that works for you and to identify steps you can take to feel more connected and grounded in your new environment.

Thanks, I really appreciate that perspective. I want to make this work, but I’m just not sure where to start with finding that balance.

Ugh, I don’t know, I guess I’m just feeling stuck. Like, I try to focus on my readings or assignments, but my mind keeps wandering to how much I miss being at home with my family, or even just having someone to chat with casually. I’ve thought about reaching out to people in my cohort more, but everyone seems so cautious about meeting up, and I get it, but it just adds to the loneliness. Do you have any ideas on how I can maybe build some kind of connection here, even if it’s small, without pushing past people’s comfort zones? And honestly, I’m still wondering if this whole grad school thing is supposed to feel this hard, or if I’m just not cut out for being so far away.

You're not alone in feeling this way, and it's important to remember that your desire for connection and balance is completely valid. Let's explore some small steps you could take to build connections in your new environment, while respecting the boundaries of those around you. Perhaps starting with virtual meetups or online study groups could be a gentle way to begin forming connections. What do you think?

Thanks for suggesting that. I think virtual meetups or online study groups could be a good starting point, especially since people seem more comfortable with that right now. I guess I’ve been hesitant to even try that because I’m worried it won’t feel like enough, you know, like it won’t really fill that gap of missing real, in-person connection. But maybe it’s better than nothing. Have you seen other students make that work, or do you have any tips on how to make those online interactions feel a bit more meaningful? And I’m still kinda wrestling with whether this level of struggle is just part of grad school or if I’m making it harder on myself by being so far from home.

It's great that you're considering virtual options as a starting point. Many students have found success in building meaningful connections through online platforms, even if it doesn't replicate the full experience of in-person interaction. One tip might be to try video calls instead of just text-based communication, as seeing someone's face can add a bit of warmth and closeness. As for the struggle of grad school, it's normal to feel overwhelmed, but your distance from home could definitely be amplifying those feelings. It might be helpful to reflect on what aspects of grad school you're enjoying and which ones feel particularly challenging right now.

Thanks for the suggestion about video calls; I think seeing people’s faces could definitely make a difference, even if it’s not the same as being there in person. I’ll try to set up something small, like a casual chat or study session over Zoom, and see how it feels.

Honestly, I do love parts of grad school—like diving into the material and the discussions when they happen—but the isolation and being so far from my support system are just weighing on me a ton. I keep wondering if I’d feel this way even without the pandemic, or if it’s just the circumstances making everything harder. Do you think it’s possible to figure out if this is just a temporary rough patch, or if maybe grad school away from home isn’t the right fit for me long-term? I don’t want to make a rash decision, but I also don’t want to keep pushing through if it’s not sustainable, you know?

It's understandable to question whether this is a temporary challenge or a sign that grad school away from home might not be the right fit for you long-term. One way to approach this could be to set a specific time frame, say a few months, to focus on implementing the small steps we've discussed—like virtual meetups and prioritizing the aspects of grad school you enjoy—while also keeping a journal to track how you feel over time. This could help you gain clarity on whether the difficulties you're facing are situational or more deeply rooted.

Thanks for that idea. Setting a time frame and journaling my feelings sounds like a practical way to figure out what’s really going on with me, without jumping to any quick conclusions.

I guess I’m just still kinda nervous about whether I’ll be able to tell the difference between a rough patch and something bigger, you know? Like, what if I keep feeling this way even after trying these steps? Do you think there are specific things I should look out for in my journaling to help me see if this is just temporary or if I need to rethink my whole plan? And honestly, I’m still worried that even if I make some connections here, it won’t be enough to make up for being so far from my family.

You’re raising some important questions, and it’s great that you’re thinking through this so carefully. When journaling, you might want to pay attention to patterns—like whether there are specific situations or times when your feelings of isolation or frustration feel more manageable, or whether there are particular moments where you feel more connected. Also, noticing how you feel after taking those small steps, like setting up virtual meetups, could give you some clues about whether those efforts are helping. And about being far from family, it might be helpful to reflect on what aspects of their support you’re missing most—whether it’s emotional, practical, or something else—and see if there are ways to replicate or adapt that support here, even if it’s not the same.

Thanks for breaking it down like that. I think focusing on specific patterns and how I feel after trying stuff like virtual meetups could really help me get a clearer picture.

Honestly, I’m still kinda stuck on this whole family thing, you know? Like, I miss just having them around for the little stuff—eating dinner together, chatting about random things, just feeling like I’m not so on my own. I’m not sure if there’s a way to recreate that here, especially with everything still so locked down. Do you think there’s anything I can do to kinda bridge that gap, even just a little, while I’m so far away? And I guess I’m also wondering if this feeling of missing them so much is gonna stick with me no matter what, or if it might get easier over time.

Thanks for the suggestions on journaling and reflecting on what I’m missing most from family. I’ll definitely try to pinpoint those specific things and see if I can find small ways to fill that gap.

I’m just still feeling pretty unsure about whether this longing for home will ever really fade, you know? Like, I want to make this work, but it’s hard to imagine feeling settled when I’m missing those everyday moments with my family so much. Do you think there’s a way to balance staying connected with them while still building something meaningful here, even if it feels so different? I guess I’m just trying to figure out how to not feel so split between two worlds all the time.

Thanks for the ideas on balancing things. I’ll try to think about ways to stay connected with my family while also building something here, even if it feels tricky right now.

I guess I’m just still worried about feeling so torn, you know? Like, I want to commit to this grad school journey, but my heart’s kinda half at home. Do you have any thoughts on how I can start to feel more whole, or at least less pulled in two directions, while I’m figuring this out?

Thanks for the input. I’m glad to have some ideas to work with on staying connected and building something here.

I’m still feeling pretty split, though, you know? Like, I want to dive into this grad school thing, but part of me is always thinking about home. Do you have any tips on how I can start feeling a bit more grounded here, even with that pull still there?

Thanks for the advice. I’ll definitely give those ideas a shot to help me feel more settled.

I guess I’m just still wondering how long it might take to feel like I really belong here, you know? Like, is there anything else I can do to make this place start feeling a bit more like home while I’m working through these feelings?

Thanks for the guidance. I’ll keep working on those suggestions to help me feel more at ease here.

I’m still kinda curious, though, about how others in similar situations have handled this, you know? Like, do you have any general insights or stories about how people far from home eventually find their footing, even if it takes time?

Thanks for sharing that curiosity. I’m glad you’re open to hearing about how others have navigated this, and I’ll definitely think about some examples or insights that might resonate with you.

Before we wrap up, I just want to check in—do you feel like we’ve covered the main things on your mind today, or is there anything else you’d like to touch on briefly?

Thanks for checking in. I think we’ve hit the main stuff I was wrestling with today, but I appreciate the space to talk it out—maybe next time we can dive a bit deeper into some of those examples if I’m still feeling stuck.
No problem, I’m glad we could cover what’s been on your mind. I’m definitely up for exploring those examples more next time if you’re still feeling stuck.

{{"reasoning": "The session identified key issues and potential strategies but hasn't yet fully explored or planned next steps. The client is still wrestling with core concerns and hasn't been offered closure.", "determination": "continue"}}
Cool, I’m looking forward to digging into that next time. Thanks again for today—it’s been really helpful to get this off my chest.
No worries, I’m glad today felt helpful. I’ll see you next time, and we’ll pick up where we left off.
Sounds good, I appreciate you making time for me. I’ll see you next time and we’ll keep the conversation going.
Thanks, I’m really glad we had this chance to talk. I’ll catch you at our next session!
Thanks, I’m glad we got to talk today too. I’ll see you at our next session!

And I guess I’m also wondering if this feeling of missing them so much is gonna stick with me no matter what, or if it might get easier over time.
client: Thanks for the suggestions on journaling and reflecting on what I’m missing most from family. I’ll definitely try to pinpoint those specific things and see if I can find small ways to fill that gap.

I’m just still feeling pretty unsure about whether this longing for home will ever really fade, you know? Like, I want to make this work, but it’s hard to imagine feeling settled when I’m missing those everyday moments with my family so much. Do you think there’s a way to balance staying connected with them while still building something meaningful here, even if it feels so different? I guess I’m just trying to figure out how to not feel so split between two worlds all the time.
client: Thanks for the ideas on balancing things. I’ll try to think about ways to stay connected with my family while also building something here, even if it feels tricky right now.

I guess I’m just still worried about feeling so torn, you know? Like, I want to commit to this grad school journey, but my heart’s kinda half at home. Do you have any thoughts on how I can start to feel more whole, or at least less pulled in two directions, while I’m figuring this out?
client: Thanks for the input. I’m glad to have some ideas to work with on staying connected and building something here.

I’m still feeling pretty split, though, you know? Like, I want to dive into this grad school thing, but part of me is always thinking about home. Do you have any tips on how I can start feeling a bit more grounded here, even with that pull still there?
client: Thanks for the advice. I’ll definitely give those ideas a shot to help me feel more settled.

I guess I’m just still wondering how long it might take to feel like I really belong here, you know? Like, is there anything else I can do to make this place start feeling a bit more like home while I’m working through these feelings?
client: Thanks for the guidance. I’ll keep working on those suggestions to help me feel more at ease here.

I’m still kinda curious, though, about how others in similar situations have handled this, you know? Like, do you have any general insights or stories about how people far from home eventually find their footing, even if it takes time?
client: Thanks for sharing that curiosity. I’m glad you’re open to hearing about how others have navigated this, and I’ll definitely think about some examples or insights that might resonate with you.

Before we wrap up, I just want to check in—do you feel like we’ve covered the main things on your mind today, or is there anything else you’d like to touch on briefly?

client: No problem, I’m glad we could cover what’s been on your mind. I’m definitely up for exploring those examples more next time if you’re still feeling stuck.
client: Cool, I’m looking forward to digging into that next time. Thanks again for today—it’s been really helpful to get this off my chest.

Created a group me that will hopefully foster some community for people to talk with one another and build some friendships or the very least camaraderie 

Here’s the link to join: You're invited to my new group 'Grad School Community' on GroupMe. Click here to join: https://groupme.com/join_group/86601776/iTupsbUn

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm excited to hear your thoughts and work together to find solutions. Please feel free to share anything that's on your mind, and we'll go from there.
Hey, thanks for having me. I’ve just been feeling really isolated in grad school lately and thought I’d bring it up to see if we can figure out some ways to cope.
It's great that you're reaching out for support, and I'm glad you feel comfortable sharing your feelings with me. Can you tell me a bit more about what's been making you feel isolated lately?
Yeah, yeah, I’m just finding it hard to connect with people who get the specific pressures I’m under. It’s like I’m in my own little bubble, and I’m hoping to find some ways to break out of it.

It sounds like you're feeling like you're carrying this weight all alone, and that can be really overwhelming. It's important to remember that you don't have to go through this by yourself, and there are people who care about you and want to help.
Thanks for saying that, it really helps to hear. I just sometimes feel like I’m missing that sense of belonging, you know, and I’m trying to figure out how to build those connections.

It's great that you're acknowledging your desire for connection and belonging, as that's an important step towards building meaningful relationships. Let's explore some ways you can start reaching out and connecting with others who may be experiencing similar pressures in grad school.
Yeah, I’m definitely open to that. I’ve even started a little group online to try and chat with other grad students, but I’m not sure yet if it’ll help or how to make it really work for me.

That's a really proactive step you've taken by starting the group, and it's great that you're open to exploring ways to make it more effective for you. I'm curious, what do you think could make the group more helpful for you and the other grad students who join?

Honestly, I’m not totally sure yet, just kinda figuring it out as I go. I guess I’d love for it to be a space where people can be real about their struggles and maybe share some laughs or advice without it feeling forced or weird.
That sounds like a really supportive and authentic space for grad students to connect. What would it look like for you if the group started to feel more natural and less forced?

Honestly, I think it’d feel natural if people just started opening up on their own, like sharing stuff without me having to poke or prod, you know? Maybe if we had some casual prompts or topics to kick things off, it could help break the ice and get convos flowing more easily.

It's great that you're thinking about how to create a space where people feel comfortable opening up and connecting naturally. Maybe we could explore some casual prompts or topics together that could help break the ice and get conversations flowing more easily.
Yeah, I’d really appreciate that. I’m kinda just winging it right now, so having some ideas to toss out there could make a big difference in getting people to chat and feel more at ease.

I'd love to help you come up with some ideas for casual prompts or topics that could help kick things off and make the group feel more natural and relaxed. What are some themes or issues that you think grad students might be able to relate to, or would be comfortable discussing?

Honestly, I think stuff like balancing workloads with personal life, or even just venting about advisor drama would hit home for a lot of us. Maybe even lighter stuff like fave study snacks or weird campus quirks could get people talking without it feeling too heavy right away.

I'm glad we're on the same page! It sounds like we have some great ideas for casual prompts that could help grad students feel comfortable opening up and connecting naturally. I can see how these topics, whether serious or lighthearted, could help kickstart meaningful conversations and make the group feel more relaxed. Do you want to start compiling a list of these ideas together, or should we brainstorm more topics first?

Hey, I’m cool with starting to compile a list of these ideas now if you are. I think we’ve got a decent mix already, but if anything else pops into my head while we’re putting it together, I’ll just throw it out there.

therapist: Awesome, let’s start putting that list together then. I’ll jot down what we’ve discussed so far, and we can build on it as more ideas come up.

client: Sounds good to me. I’m excited to see how this shapes up and get some solid convo starters ready.
