concern:
Hi y'all. I (f22) am graduating next semester and I can't tell you how I regret every bit of it. The friends I made, the parties I went to, my poor mental health. It destroyed my trajectory. I can put some of the blame on the pandemic. After covid hit, I decided to take a semester off. I lost all my passion, didn't know what job I wanted, and was distracted by boys and friends and freedom. I didn't know I had undiagnosed depression and ADHD. I went back to school, but to a community college. Waste of time, all those classes meant nothing at a 4 year university. Refused to go back to my original school and went somewhere an hour away. I said it was for the instate tuition. I was really just scared of returning to a place I felt so depressed and lost when I was 18. When I finally returned to my original university, the one that actually had the best opportunities, I had wasted all that time. If I want to graduate on time, and I do, I can't indulge in all the opportunities.

I messed up my academics, my friends, my health (mental and physical). Use me as an example and set school as a priority. Its something everyone tells you and everyone brushes it off. Well, surprise surprise. Should've listened.

Any similar thoughts or feelings; whether it's over devotion to school or missed chances? Regret this large is new to me.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there! It's so great to have you here. I'm all ears, ready to listen and support you in any way I can. What's on your mind today?
Hey, thanks for being here. I’m just really overwhelmed with regret about how my college years have gone and the choices I’ve made.

That sounds really tough. It can be hard to come to terms with the choices we've made and the path we've taken. I'm here to listen and help you work through these feelings, if you're comfortable sharing more about what's been going through your mind.
client: Thanks, I appreciate that. I just keep thinking about how I let so many things slip through my fingers, and now I’m scrambling to make up for lost time.
It's understandable to feel that way, especially when looking back and thinking about what could have been. Can you tell me more about what you feel slipped through your fingers?

Hey, yeah, I just feel like I missed out on so many chances to build a solid foundation for my future, you know? It’s like I was so caught up in everything else that I didn’t focus on what really mattered.

I guess I’m just stuck on how I could’ve done things differently, and it’s eating at me. Like, I see other people my age who seem to have it all together, and I’m just… not there. Does that make sense? I don’t even know where to start fixing this mess.

I can hear how much this weighs on you, and it's completely understandable to feel that way. You're not alone in this struggle, and we can start by exploring what you hope to achieve, and then work on building a plan together.

Thanks, that means a lot to hear. I guess I just wanna get to a place where I feel like I’m moving forward, not stuck in this regret loop, ya know? Like, I wanna figure out how to make the most of what’s left of my time in school and beyond, but I’m kinda clueless on how to even start setting those goals or whatever. Where do we even begin with something like that?

I understand your desire to move forward and make the most of your time. We can start by exploring your strengths, values, and aspirations, and work from there to identify goals that align with who you are and what you want to achieve.

Cool, that sounds like a solid way to go. I’m just not super sure what my strengths even are right now, or like, what I really wanna do, so I hope we can figure that out together. Where do we start with digging into that stuff? I’m kinda all over the place, but I’m ready to try.

We can begin by reflecting on your past experiences and accomplishments, identifying moments when you felt most fulfilled or proud of yourself. This will help us uncover your strengths and values. It might also be helpful to think about the kind of person you aspire to be, and the things that bring you joy and fulfillment. Let's take this one step at a time, and work together to create a clearer picture of your aspirations and strengths.

Hey, that sounds like a good plan to me. I’m down to take it slow and figure out what’s been meaningful to me, even if it’s hard to see right now with all the mess in my head.

So, like, when you say reflecting on past experiences, do you mean stuff from school or just life in general? I’ve got some things I’m kinda proud of, but I’m not sure if they’re even relevant to where I wanna go. And honestly, I’m a little scared to dig too deep ‘cause I feel like I’ll just get stuck on the bad stuff again. How do we make sure I don’t spiral back into that regret thing while we’re doing this?

That's a great question. When I say reflecting on past experiences, I mean both school and life in general. Any experience that has left an impact on you, whether positive or challenging, can provide valuable insights into your strengths and values. It's natural to feel apprehensive about revisiting past regrets, but we can work together to ensure that we focus on what you've learned from those experiences rather than getting stuck on the negative emotions. We can also take breaks or shift the focus if you start to feel overwhelmed, so you're always in control of the process.

Thanks for explaining that. I like the idea of focusing on what I’ve learned instead of just the bad feelings, and knowing we can take breaks if it gets too heavy really helps.

So, I guess I’m ready to start thinking about some of those moments. Like, I remember feeling pretty good when I helped organize a small fundraiser for a club in high school, and I felt proud of pulling it together even though I was super shy back then. But I’m not sure how that connects to anything now, ya know? How do we take something like that and figure out if it’s a strength or just a random thing I did once?

That's a great example to start with! Let's unpack it together. What stood out to you about that experience? What skills or qualities do you think you used when you helped organize that fundraiser? Maybe we can find some clues there.

Hey, I’m glad we’re diving into this. I think what stood out was just seeing it all come together, like, I somehow got people to show up and we raised more than I expected, which felt kinda cool. I guess I had to talk to a bunch of people, even though I was shy, and figure out how to plan stuff step by step. I’m not sure if that’s a real skill or just something I stumbled through, though. How do we tell if that’s something I’m actually good at or if it was just a fluke?

That's a great observation. It sounds like you used some valuable skills like communication, planning, and maybe even some leadership abilities. Let's explore that a bit further. What do you think helped you push past your shyness and connect with people for the fundraiser?

Hey, I’m glad we’re digging into this. I think what helped me push past my shyness was just knowing it was for a good cause, like, I really cared about making it happen, so I kinda forced myself to talk to people even if it felt awkward at first. I guess I also had a friend in the club who kinda hyped me up, which made it easier to step out of my comfort zone. How do we figure out if that’s something I can still tap into now, especially when I’m feeling so unsure about everything?

It sounds like your passion for the cause and having support from a friend really helped you step up and push past your shyness. That determination and ability to seek support are great strengths that you can still tap into now. How do you think you could use those strengths to help you move forward with the challenges you're facing today?

Hey, I’m glad we’re connecting those dots. I think maybe I could try leaning on that determination by focusing on something I care about now, like figuring out my next steps after graduation, even if it feels overwhelming. And maybe reaching out to friends or mentors for support could help me feel less stuck, like it did back then. How do I start small with that, though, without feeling like I’m just gonna mess it up again?

Starting small could look like identifying one specific area you care about, like researching career paths or reaching out to one friend for support. This way, you can build momentum without feeling overwhelmed. What’s one step you could take this week that aligns with your determination and desire for support?

Hey, I’m glad we’re breaking this down into manageable pieces. I think one step I could take this week is maybe sending a quick message to a friend or a mentor about grabbing coffee or just chatting about post-grad ideas, something low-pressure to get the ball rolling. How do I keep myself from overthinking it and backing out at the last second?

That sounds like a great first step! To avoid overthinking, you could try setting a specific time to send that message and commit to it, like scheduling a reminder on your phone. Remember, this is just a casual chat to start building momentum, and it’s okay if it feels a bit awkward at first—just like with the fundraiser, taking that initial step can help you grow more confident over time.

Hey, I appreciate the reminder to keep it casual and just take that first step. I’ll set a time on my phone to send that message so I don’t keep putting it off, and try to remind myself it’s not a big deal, just a convo. How do I deal with the nerves that pop up right before I hit send, though, ‘cause I know I’m gonna feel all jittery about it?

To manage those nerves, try grounding techniques like taking a few deep breaths or repeating a short, empowering phrase to yourself—like “I’ve got this” or “I’m taking a step forward.” It’s normal to feel jittery, but those feelings don’t have to stop you from moving forward. Once you hit send, you might even feel a sense of relief, just like you did after stepping up for the fundraiser.

Hey, thanks for the grounding idea. I’ll definitely try the deep breaths and maybe say “I’ve got this” to myself before I send the message, just to calm those jitters a bit. I guess I’m just worried about how they’ll respond, or if they’ll even care to chat—how do I handle it if it feels like I’m being brushed off or if it doesn’t go the way I hope?

Hey, I hear you—anticipating their response can be nerve-wracking, but remember, you’re reaching out for support, not for a perfect outcome. If it feels like they’re brushing you off, you could try rephrasing your message to clarify your intent, like “Hey, I’d love to grab coffee sometime to talk about post-grad ideas—I know you’re busy, but even a quick chat would mean a lot to me.” And if it doesn’t go as planned, that’s okay too.

Hey, thanks for that perspective—it’s helpful to remember I’m just reaching out for support, not expecting everything to be perfect. I’ll keep that rephrasing idea in mind if I feel like I’m not getting through, and try not to take it too personally if it doesn’t work out. I guess I’m also worried about feeling like I’m bothering them, you know? Like, what if I’m just adding to their stress or they don’t have time for me—how do I shake that feeling of being a burden when I’m trying to connect?

Hey, I’m really glad you brought that up because that feeling of being a burden can be so heavy. To ease that worry, you might remind yourself that reaching out is a normal part of building connections—most people appreciate being thought of, even if they’re busy. If it helps, you could even start the message by acknowledging their time, like saying, “Hey, I know you’ve got a lot on your plate, but I’d love to chat if you’ve got a minute.” How does that sound to you?

Hey, that sounds like a good approach—acknowledging their time upfront feels respectful and might take some of the pressure off me. I’ll give that a shot and try to keep in mind that reaching out is just a normal thing, not a burden. I guess I’m still a bit anxious about overthinking their tone or response time—any quick tips to stop myself from spiraling on that?

Hey, I’m glad you think that approach could work for you. A quick tip to avoid overthinking their tone or response time is to set a mental boundary—like deciding not to check for a reply constantly and focusing on something else you enjoy in the meantime. How do you feel about trying that to keep your mind from spinning?

Hey, that’s a solid idea—I think setting a mental boundary and distracting myself with something I enjoy could really help keep me from overanalyzing every little thing. Do you have any other quick tricks for staying grounded if I start feeling anxious about it again?

client: Hey, thanks for being here. I’m just really overwhelmed with regret about how my college years have gone and the choices I’ve made.
therapist: That sounds really tough. It can be hard to come to terms with the choices we've made and the path we've taken. I'm here to listen and help you work through these feelings, if you're comfortable sharing more about what's been going through your mind.

client: Hey, yeah, I just feel like I missed out on so many chances to build a solid foundation for my future, you know? It’s like I was so caught up in everything else that I didn’t focus on what really mattered.

I guess I’m just stuck on how I could’ve done things differently, and it’s eating at me. Like, I see other people my age who seem to have it all together, and I’m just… not there. Does that make sense? I don’t even know where to start fixing this mess.
therapist: I can hear how much this weighs on you, and it's completely understandable to feel that way. You're not alone in this struggle, and we can start by exploring what you hope to achieve, and then work on building a plan together.
client: Thanks, that means a lot to hear. I guess I just wanna get to a place where I feel like I’m moving forward, not stuck in this regret loop, ya know? Like, I wanna figure out how to make the most of what’s left of my time in school and beyond, but I’m kinda clueless on how to even start setting those goals or whatever. Where do we even begin with something like that?
therapist: I understand your desire to move forward and make the most of your time. We can start by exploring your strengths, values, and aspirations, and work from there to identify goals that align with who you are and what you want to achieve.
client: Cool, that sounds like a solid way to go. I’m just not super sure what my strengths even are right now, or like, what I really wanna do, so I hope we can figure that out together. Where do we start with digging into that stuff? I’m kinda all over the place, but I’m ready to try.
therapist: We can begin by reflecting on your past experiences and accomplishments, identifying moments when you felt most fulfilled or proud of yourself. Let's take this one step at a time, and work together to create a clearer picture of your aspirations and strengths.
client: Hey, that sounds like a good plan to me. I’m down to take it slow and figure out what’s been meaningful to me, even if it’s hard to see right now with all the mess in my head.

I’ve got some things I’m kinda proud of, but I’m not sure if they’re even relevant to where I wanna go. therapist: That's a great question. When I say reflecting on past experiences, I mean both school and life in general. Any experience that has left an impact on you, whether positive or challenging, can provide valuable insights into your strengths and values. It's natural to feel apprehensive about revisiting past regrets, but we can work together to ensure that we focus on what you've learned from those experiences rather than getting stuck on the negative emotions. We can also take breaks or shift the focus if you start to feel overwhelmed, so you're always in control of the process.
client: Thanks for explaining that. I like the idea of focusing on what I’ve learned instead of just the bad feelings, and knowing we can take breaks if it gets too heavy really helps.

So, I guess I’m ready to start thinking about some of those moments. therapist: That's a great example to start with! Let's unpack it together. What stood out to you about that experience? What skills or qualities do you think you used when you helped organize that fundraiser? Maybe we can find some clues there.

therapist: That's a great observation. It sounds like you used some valuable skills like communication, planning, and maybe even some leadership abilities. Let's explore that a bit further. What do you think helped you push past your shyness and connect with people for the fundraiser?
client: Hey, I’m glad we’re digging into this. concern:
Hey, so I'm going to CSUS and taking the ALEKs Math test very soon and I'm very worried I wont do well because this math goes very far back and there's lots of things I've forgotten. I've taken all the possible math courses at my high school- all the way up to Calculus AB and BC (but I didn't pass the AP test so I have to take calculus in college) and I'm currently in AP Stats. I'm just worried that if I bomb this test they're going to put me in a super low math class. 

In all the math classes I've taken I've gotten A's so... would they still put me in a low math class if I bomb the test even though my transcript shows that I've aced all the higher math classes I've taken? 

I would really appreciate any help/responses because this has been stressing me out a lot. Also, maybe this isn't the correct subreddit to post this question in, so I apologize if that's the case. But, I couldn't find a better place and this still applies to college and applications.

dialogue_total.statement: Hey there, welcome to our session! I'm here to listen and support you, so feel free to share whatever's on your mind. Is there something specific you'd like to talk about, or shall we start with whatever feels most important to you right now?

Hey, thanks for being here. I’m really stressed about this upcoming ALEKS Math test at CSUS, and I just wanted to talk through my worries about potentially not doing well and what that might mean for my class placement.

That sounds really overwhelming—I can understand why you’d feel stressed about it. It’s okay to have those worries, and I’m here to help you unpack them. Can you tell me a bit more about what’s been on your mind lately regarding the test?

Client: Yeah, for sure. I’m just kinda freaking out because I’ve forgotten a lot of the older math stuff, even though I’ve taken all the high school math courses up to Calculus AB and BC, and I’m worried if I mess up this test, they’ll stick me in some super basic class despite my grades being good.

That’s a valid concern, especially with all the hard work you've put into your math education. It can be frustrating when you feel like your past efforts might not be recognized, and it's understandable that you're worried about being placed in a class that doesn't reflect your true abilities. What do you think would happen if you did end up in a lower-level class?

Client: Ugh, I just feel like it’d be such a waste of time, ya know? Like, I’ve already spent years getting through all those tough math classes with good grades, and having to redo stuff I’ve technically already learned would be so frustrating and might even mess up my schedule or delay my progress.

I can see why that would be frustrating and stressful. It sounds like you're worried about feeling like you're being held back and not able to move forward with your studies. Can you tell me more about what you've been doing to prepare for the test so far?

Client: Yeah, honestly, I’ve been trying to brush up on some old math concepts, like going through Khan Academy videos and some old textbooks, but it’s kinda overwhelming with all the stuff I’ve forgotten. I’m just worried it won’t be enough, and I don’t even know if I’m focusing on the right topics for the ALEKS test.

I can see how trying to cover all the forgotten material might feel like an uphill battle. It's great that you're taking proactive steps with Khan Academy and textbooks, but maybe focusing on the most critical topics for the ALEKS test could help streamline your studying and reduce the sense of overwhelm. Have you considered checking the test's official website or study guide for a detailed breakdown of the topics covered?

Client: Yeah, I did look at the ALEKS website a bit, but it’s kinda vague, and I’m not totally sure what’s most important to focus on. I guess I could dig deeper or maybe ask someone at CSUS for a better idea, but I’m just feeling so short on time and kinda panicking about it.

It sounds like you're doing your best to prepare, but the uncertainty around what topics to focus on is adding to your stress. I understand how overwhelming it can feel when you're short on time and unsure about where to direct your efforts. Perhaps we could explore ways to break down the material into more manageable chunks or prioritize the most essential topics together?

Client: Yeah, that sounds like it could help a lot. I’m just kinda lost on where to even start breaking it down, and I’m worried I’ll miss something big, ya know? Like, if you’ve got any ideas on how to organize this mess of math stuff or figure out what’s most important for the test, I’m all ears.

I hear how important this is for you, and it's okay to feel a bit lost. What if we start by looking at the test's official website or study guide again, and see if there are any specific sections or topics that are emphasized? Sometimes breaking it down into smaller, more focused areas can make it feel more manageable.

**Therapist:** I’m glad you’re open to working through this together, and I understand how daunting it can feel to tackle such a broad range of topics. Let’s take a structured approach by identifying key areas from the ALEKS framework and creating a priority list to focus your energy on—does that sound like a good starting point?

**Client:** Yeah, that sounds way better than just randomly studying everything. Can we maybe make like a quick list or schedule or something right now? I just wanna feel like I’ve got a grip on this, ya know, instead of feeling like I’m drowning in math problems.

Absolutely, let's start building that list together! What if we look at the ALEKS framework and identify the top three to five most critical topics for the test? We can then prioritize those areas and create a study schedule that fits your time constraints. Does that sound like a good way to start?
**Client:** Yeah, that sounds perfect actually. Let’s do that—figuring out those top topics and making a schedule would really help me feel like I’ve got some control over this, ya know?

Let's start by identifying those key topics from the ALEKS framework. What areas do you feel are most challenging or require the most attention? We can prioritize those first to build your confidence and create a schedule around them.

**Client:** Honestly, I think algebra and trig are the ones that scare me the most right now. I mean, I did okay in them back in high school, but it’s been a while, and I feel like I’ve forgotten a ton of the formulas and stuff, ya know? Can we start with those and maybe figure out a way to review them without it taking forever?

Absolutely, let's prioritize algebra and trigonometry to start! We can break these topics down into manageable chunks by focusing on the most commonly tested areas, like solving equations, functions, and identities. I'll help you create a schedule that allows you to review these topics efficiently without feeling overwhelmed. Does that sound like a good approach?

**Client:** Yeah, that sounds really doable. Breaking it down like that makes it feel less intimidating, and I’m kinda relieved to just focus on the big stuff first, ya know? Can we maybe set up, like, specific days or times to go over each part so I don’t just keep putting it off?

therapist: Of course, setting specific days and times is a great idea to keep you on track. How about we look at your weekly schedule together and carve out dedicated slots for algebra and trig review, making sure they’re realistic for your other commitments?

client: **Client:** Yeah, I’d appreciate that a lot. Let’s figure out some times that won’t clash with my classes or work, ‘cause I really wanna stick to this without stressing out more.

concern:
All throughout my academic career I have gotten straight As but I feel like that pressure I put on myself to maintain this is detrimental to my mental health. I will spiral into depression and panic if I don't do that well on a test or get B's and C's, even if I only need at D to pass. 

For my major (CS), my GPA doesn't matter a whole lot but I still can't shake the need to get and maintain a 4.0. I want to be able to enjoy extracurriculars, hobbies and things outside of school but I feel trapped by my own mind.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm here to listen and support you without judgment. Please feel free to share whatever's been on your mind or in your heart - it's all welcome here.
Thanks for being here to listen. I’ve just been really overwhelmed with the pressure I put on myself to keep up perfect grades, and it’s honestly taking a toll on me.

It sounds like you've been carrying a heavy load, and that pressure has been really weighing you down. I'm glad you're here to talk about it. Can you tell me more about what that pressure feels like for you?

It feels like this constant weight on my chest, like if I don’t hit that perfect mark, I’ve completely failed myself. It’s exhausting, and I just can’t seem to let go of it, even though I know it’s not the end of the world.

That constant weight on your chest sounds incredibly draining, and it’s understandable that you feel like you can’t let go of it, even when you know it’s not the end of the world. Can you tell me more about what you think would happen if you did let go of that pressure, even just a little bit?

Honestly, I think I’d feel like I’m losing control or like I’m not good enough if I let go of that pressure, even just a bit. It’s weird because I know logically it wouldn’t be a big deal, but emotionally, it feels like I’d be giving up on who I am.

It sounds like the pressure you put on yourself is tied closely to your sense of identity, and letting go of it feels like a betrayal of who you are. It's interesting that you can see the logic in letting go of some of that pressure, but emotionally, it feels like you'd be losing a part of yourself.

Yeah, exactly, it’s like my whole sense of self is wrapped up in being the person who always gets it right. I don’t even know who I’d be without that, and it scares me to think about not pushing myself so hard.

It sounds like your sense of self-worth is deeply intertwined with your ability to perform perfectly, and the idea of letting go of that pressure is daunting because it feels like you'd be abandoning a part of yourself. It's understandable that this would be a scary thought, and it's interesting that you recognize the emotional attachment to this pressure even when logically you know it's not the end of the world.

Yeah, it’s like I can see that it’s not healthy to tie my worth to my grades, but I just can’t seem to separate the two in my head. I’m scared that if I stop pushing for perfection, I’ll just spiral into feeling worthless or like I’ve lost my purpose.

It sounds like you’re caught in a paradox where your pursuit of perfection feels like the only way to maintain your sense of self, yet it’s also the source of your exhaustion and distress. That must be a really challenging place to be. Can you think of any small steps you might take to begin to separate your self-worth from your academic performance, even if just in your mind?

Honestly, I’m not even sure where to start with separating my self-worth from my grades—it feels so ingrained in me. Maybe I could try focusing on something outside of school, like a hobby or club, but I’m worried I’ll just end up stressing about not being good at that too.

It sounds like you're already recognizing the need for self-worth beyond academic performance, even if the path forward feels uncertain. Focusing on a hobby or club could be a good start, and maybe the key is to approach it with a mindset of exploration rather than perfection. Have you ever tried engaging in an activity without worrying about being good at it?

Honestly, not really—I’ve always felt like I need to excel at everything I do, even stuff outside of school. It’s like I can’t let myself just enjoy something without turning it into another thing I have to be the best at.

It sounds like you've always felt a strong need to excel at everything you do, which has prevented you from enjoying activities without feeling pressured to be the best at them. It might be helpful to explore the idea of approaching a hobby or club with a mindset of exploration rather than perfection. Perhaps you could try engaging in an activity with the intention of simply enjoying it, without any expectations or pressure to perform well. Have you considered any hobbies or clubs that you might be interested in trying?

Yeah, I’ve thought about maybe joining a coding club or something related to my major, just to mess around with projects without the grade pressure. I also kinda like the idea of something totally unrelated, like hiking or a book club, but I’m nervous I’ll still put that same perfectionist spin on it.

That’s understandable—old habits can be hard to shake, but it’s great that you’re aware of that potential pitfall. Maybe you could try approaching these activities with the mindset of an explorer, like you’re discovering something new just for the fun of it. How do you think you could keep yourself from slipping into that perfectionist mindset, especially when trying something outside of your comfort zone?

I guess I could try setting some boundaries for myself, like reminding myself that it’s okay to just participate without aiming to be the best. Maybe I could also focus on the process, like enjoying the hike or the discussion, instead of worrying about some imaginary standard I’ve gotta meet.

That’s a great start! By setting boundaries and focusing on the process, you can allow yourself to enjoy the experience without the pressure of perfection. Another idea might be to remind yourself that it’s okay to make mistakes or not be the best at something, and that the value lies in the experience itself rather than the outcome.

Yeah, I like the idea of just letting myself mess up and not caring so much about the result. I think I’ll have to keep repeating that to myself, though, ‘cause it’s so easy to fall back into old patterns. How do you think I can keep that mindset when I’m actually in the middle of doing something new and feeling that urge to overachieve?

Therapist: That’s a really insightful question. One way to maintain that mindset is to pause and check in with yourself during the activity—ask, “Am I enjoying this for what it is, or am I pushing for a goal?” You could also set a small, intentional reminder, like a note on your phone or a quick mental cue, to refocus on the fun rather than the outcome. How does that sound to you?

Client: That sounds doable, like a little reality check to keep me grounded. I’ll probably need to practice it a bunch, but I’m willing to give it a shot. So, do you think I should start with something low-stakes first, just to ease into this whole “enjoying without pressure” thing?

concern:
For the past year and half, my college have has been difficult.  I often worked 40-50 hour weeks and when I got home had no motivation to study. Not to say I didn't I passed at least one class per semester. Yet my gpa was 0.22 something incredibly low 

A year and half later and now I'm on academic suspension. I feel sick from this revelation and I don't know why.

Any advice or words of wisdom because I was told to never stop but I can progress with this suspension in my way

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our counseling session today! I'm here to listen and support you, so please feel free to share whatever thoughts or concerns you have on your mind. Take your time, and let's work through this together. 😊
Hey, thanks for being here. I’m just really overwhelmed with this academic suspension and feeling pretty lost about what to do next.

That must be a really tough place to be in, feeling overwhelmed and unsure of what to do next. It takes a lot of courage to share this, and I'm here to listen and support you. Can you tell me more about what's been going on with your academic suspension?
Hey, yeah, it’s been a rough ride, and I’m just kinda reeling from the whole suspension thing. I guess I’m trying to figure out how I even got here and what steps I can take to bounce back.

It sounds like you're feeling a mix of confusion and frustration, trying to make sense of how things got to this point. It's understandable that you'd want to figure out how to bounce back from this setback. I'm here to help you navigate these feelings and work through the steps that might be helpful for you.
Thanks for understanding where I’m at right now. I just feel like I’ve hit a wall and don’t even know where to start climbing over it.

It's completely understandable to feel like you've hit a wall, and I can imagine how frustrating and overwhelming that must be. It's important to remember that setbacks like this are a part of life, and it's okay to take your time to process and figure out the next steps. I'm here to support you, and we can take things one step at a time together.
Hey, I really appreciate that, knowing I don’t have to rush through this mess. I guess I’m just worried about how to even begin picking up the pieces, ya know?

I hear you, it can feel really daunting to start picking up the pieces when things seem so overwhelming. Let's take a step back and try to focus on one small step at a time. Can you tell me about one thing you feel might be a good place to start?

Honestly, I’m not even sure where to start, it all feels like such a mess. Maybe just figuring out what went wrong with my study habits or time management could be a first step, but I don’t know how to dig into that without feeling worse about myself.
It's okay to take your time and figure things out at your own pace. What if we started by simply reflecting on how your study habits and time management have been impacting your goals lately?
Yeah, I think reflecting on that could help, even if it’s hard to look at. I just don’t want to end up feeling more stuck or beating myself up over past mistakes, ya know?

I hear you, and it's completely understandable to want to avoid feeling stuck or beating yourself up. Let's focus on understanding the impact of your study habits and time management in a way that feels manageable and non-judgmental. Can you tell me more about how you think your current habits might be affecting your progress toward your goals?

Yeah, I can try to break it down, even if it’s kinda tough to think about. I guess I’ve been so overwhelmed with long work hours that I just crash when I get home, and studying feels like the last thing I can handle, so I keep putting it off.

I hear you. It sounds like you're caught in a cycle where work and exhaustion are making it hard to make progress on your goals. What if we focused on how making even small changes to your study habits and time management might help break this cycle and create more balance in your life?

Yeah, I’m open to trying small changes, ‘cause right now it feels like I’m just spinning my wheels. I just don’t know where to even start with balancing everything without feeling like I’m dropping the ball somewhere else.

That makes sense. It can be overwhelming to balance everything, especially when you're already feeling exhausted. What if we explored some small, realistic adjustments to your routine that could create a bit more space for studying without adding to your stress? Maybe even one or two things that feel doable right now?

Yeah, I’d be down to look at some small tweaks to my routine, ‘cause I really need something that doesn’t feel like a huge burden. Like, if we can figure out just a couple things I can actually stick to, that’d be a start, ya know?

Alright, let's start with what feels manageable. What if we look at your current routine and find a couple of small adjustments that could create some space for studying without adding to your stress? Maybe something like carving out a specific time slot each day, or adjusting your work hours slightly to allow for some study time?
Yeah, that sounds doable, like maybe finding a specific time each day could help me get into a rhythm. I’m just worried I’ll still feel too drained after work to actually stick with it, ya know?

It’s understandable that feeling drained after work could make sticking to a new routine challenging. What if we considered how you might recharge a bit before diving into studying, like taking a short walk, listening to music, or even just having a cup of tea? Maybe we could also look at your work schedule and see if there’s a way to adjust your hours slightly to give you some more energy for studying?

Yeah, I like the idea of recharging a bit before jumping into studying, like maybe a quick walk or just chilling with some music could help reset my head. I’m not sure about adjusting work hours yet, though—my schedule’s pretty locked in, but I’m open to brainstorming ways to make it work.

Great! It sounds like taking a moment to recharge could make a big difference. What if we focused on building a short, daily routine that includes both your recharging activity and a manageable study session? Maybe we could start with just one or two days a week, to see what works best for you?

Yeah, starting with just one or two days a week sounds way less intimidating, and I think I could handle that without feeling overwhelmed. I’m cool with trying a short routine that mixes in some recharging and studying—let’s see how it goes, ya know?

therapist: I’m glad you’re open to giving this a try. Let’s check in next session to see how it’s working and tweak anything if needed—does that sound good to you?

client: Yeah, that sounds perfect. I’ll keep track of how it feels and let you know next time.

concern: I’m going back to college after doing 6 years in the Navy and honestly, I’m extremely stressed/worried. I’m 26 now and more mature than my first time in college but I’m still super worried about everything from making sure my classes/financial aid being set to making sure  I can actually pass all of my classes. Any tips or recommendations from anyone experiencing a similar situation? I made a big bet on myself and I’m hoping I didn’t make the wrong decision.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there! I'm really glad you're here today. I'm ready to listen and support you in any way I can, so please feel free to share whatever's on your mind or in your heart.
Hey, thanks for being here. I’m just feeling really overwhelmed with going back to school after the Navy and worried I might not be able to handle everything.

That’s completely understandable, and I’m really glad you shared that with me. Going back to school after such a significant change like transitioning from the Navy can be really overwhelming, and it’s okay to feel worried about handling everything. I’m here to listen and support you, and I’d love to hear more about what’s been on your mind lately.
Thanks, I appreciate that. I guess I’m just stuck on whether I’ve made the right choice jumping back into college, and I’m nervous about keeping up with everything.

It sounds like you're feeling a bit uncertain about your decision to go back to school, and that's completely normal, especially after such a significant change. It's natural to have some doubts and worries about keeping up with everything. I'm here to listen and help you work through those feelings if you'd like to share more about what's been on your mind.

Thanks for understanding. I’m just really questioning if I’m cut out for this after being out of the academic game for so long, you know? Like, I’ve got a lot riding on this, and I don’t wanna mess it up.

It sounds like you're putting a lot of pressure on yourself, and it's completely natural to feel that way after being out of the academic game for so long. I can imagine how much is riding on this, and it's okay to feel uncertain. Would you like to talk more about what's making you feel like you might not be cut out for this?

Yeah, I’d like to dive into that a bit. I just keep thinking that I’ve been out of school for so long, my brain might not be wired for studying anymore, and I’m scared I’ll fall behind or not get the hang of things fast enough.

It sounds like you're concerned about your ability to adapt to the academic environment after being away for so long, and that's a valid worry. But remember, you've already made the first step by starting college, and that's something to be proud of. What are some things you think could help you get back into the swing of studying, and how could we work together to make that happen?

I’m glad you see it as a step forward, and I do wanna figure this out. Honestly, I’m not even sure where to start—maybe some kinda structure or tips on how to study again, since I feel so rusty, and just having someone to check in with might help me stay on track.

You've already taken an important step by acknowledging the need for structure and support, and I'm here to help you find the tools and strategies that work best for you. Let's start by exploring what study habits or techniques have helped you in the past, and how we can build on those strengths to create a plan that feels manageable and empowering.

Cool, I appreciate that. I guess in the past, I did okay with breaking stuff down into smaller chunks and setting little goals, but it’s been so long I’m not sure if that’ll still work for me, you know?

It's great that you're recalling strategies that worked for you in the past—those strengths are still a part of you, even after a break. What if we started by testing out one small goal or chunked task this week, just to see how it feels? That way, you can get a sense of what still works for you and what might need a fresh approach.
Hey, that sounds like a solid plan. I’m down to try setting a small goal this week and see how it goes, even if I’m a bit nervous about whether I can stick to it.

That’s a great mindset to approach this with! It’s completely normal to feel a bit nervous when trying something new, especially after a break. Let’s work together to identify a manageable first step and create a plan to support you in achieving it. What’s one small, specific goal you feel you can realistically tackle this week, and what resources or support systems might help you stay on track?

I think I can start with something simple like reviewing one chapter of a textbook or setting aside an hour to organize my notes, just to get back into the groove. I’m not sure what support I’ll need yet, but maybe just checking in with you or a study group could keep me accountable—what do you think?

I think that sounds like a great starting point, and it’s awesome that you’re thinking about accountability! Let’s build on that by exploring what specific check-in or support structure might work best for you, whether it’s a quick text reminder or a weekly call, and how we can tailor it to fit your needs.

That sounds good to me. I think maybe a quick text reminder could help keep me on track without feeling too overwhelming, and I’d be cool with touching base with you weekly to see how I’m doing. So, how do we set that up, like, do I just shoot you a message if I’m struggling or is there a specific time we check in?
I'm glad we're figuring this out together. Can we maybe set a specific day and time for the weekly check-in so I know when to expect it, and I’ll just text you if something comes up before then?

client: I'm glad we're figuring this out together. Can we maybe set a specific day and time for the weekly check-in so I know when to expect it, and I’ll just text you if something comes up before then?

concern: Do other people get very easily distracted or bored or frustrated when reading articles or portions of the text book for class? I love to read, I have a huge collection of books, but when it comes to reading anything written to educate or for the academic world it feels like stabbing my eyes out. Does anyone else feel like this? How do you cope/get around that?

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm so glad you're here to share your thoughts and feelings with me. Please take your time to express whatever's on your mind—I'm all ears and ready to listen with empathy and understanding.
Hey, thanks for having me. I’m just really struggling with staying focused on academic reading, and I’m hoping to figure out some ways to deal with it.

That sounds really tough, and I can imagine how frustrating it must feel when you're trying to focus but your mind keeps wandering. Can you tell me a bit more about what happens when you're trying to read and how it makes you feel?

Yeah, it’s like my brain just shuts off the second I open a textbook or article, and I end up rereading the same paragraph over and over without taking anything in. It makes me feel super annoyed and kinda defeated, like I’m not cut out for this grad school stuff.

It’s totally understandable to feel that way when your brain seems to be working against you, and it’s important to acknowledge how much courage it takes to face these challenges head-on. It might help to explore what’s going on in those moments when your focus starts to slip—do you notice any particular triggers or patterns that could be contributing to it?

Honestly, I think it’s just the dry, dense style of academic stuff that throws me off, like there’s no story or hook to keep me engaged. I also sometimes catch myself worrying about deadlines or other assignments, which just makes it harder to stay in the moment with the reading.

You're describing a really common struggle with academic reading, and it's interesting that you bring up the lack of storytelling in the material. It sounds like your brain is craving that narrative engagement, and it's not getting it, which makes it harder to stay focused. It's also understandable that deadlines and other responsibilities can weigh heavily on your mind and make it even more difficult to concentrate. Let's see if we can explore some strategies that might help make academic reading feel more engaging and less overwhelming.

Cool, I’m definitely open to trying some new approaches because right now, it just feels like a slog every time I pick up something for class. What kind of strategies do you think might help trick my brain into actually caring about this stuff?

That’s a great question, and it’s clear you’re motivated to find solutions. One approach could be to incorporate storytelling techniques into your reading process, like creating a narrative around the material or relating it to real-life scenarios. Another strategy might involve breaking tasks into smaller, more manageable chunks, and using the Pomodoro Technique to help maintain focus and avoid feeling overwhelmed by deadlines.

Nice, I like the idea of making a story out of the material—that might actually make it feel less like a chore. How would I even start doing that with something as dry as a research article or textbook chapter?

One way to start creating a story around dry material is to ask yourself questions like, ""What problem is this research trying to solve?"" or ""How might this information affect someone's life in a real-world situation?"" By reframing the content as a problem to be solved or a story with characters and consequences, you can engage your brain's natural desire for narrative and make the information more memorable and interesting. Would you be willing to try that with your next reading assignment?

Yeah, I’m totally willing to give that a shot—turning it into a problem or story sounds like it could make things click better for me. Do you think I should, like, write out the story or just kinda think it through in my head while I’m reading?

I'm glad you're open to trying this strategy. It's up to you whether you'd like to write out the story or just think it through mentally. Some people find that writing helps solidify the narrative, while others prefer to mentally connect the dots. Experiment with both methods to see what works best for you.

Cool, I’ll play around with both writing it out and just thinking it through to see what sticks better for me. I’m kinda curious if putting pen to paper will make it feel more real or if it’ll just slow me down, ya know?

That's a great idea, and it's awesome that you're open to exploring both methods. You might find that writing it out helps you visualize the story better, while mentally connecting the dots could keep your reading process flowing smoothly. Either way, it's all about finding what works best for you and your learning style.

Hey, thanks for the encouragement—I’m glad to experiment with this and figure out what fits my vibe. Do you think there’s a chance this storytelling thing might not work for all kinds of readings, like super technical stuff, or should I just push through and try it anyway?

It's definitely worth giving it a shot with all kinds of readings, even the super technical stuff. You might find that it helps you connect the technical details to real-world scenarios, making them more relatable and memorable. If you encounter any obstacles while trying this approach with technical material, we can work together to find ways to adapt the strategy to fit your needs.

Cool, I appreciate that we can tweak it if needed. I’m a bit worried that with the really dense, technical readings, turning it into a story might feel forced or just not click, but I’m down to try and see what happens.

I understand your concerns about technical material, but it's great that you're willing to give it a shot. You might find that storytelling helps you organize complex information in a more manageable way, even if it takes a little more effort at first. Remember, it's okay if it doesn't work perfectly right away—we can adjust the approach as needed.
Yeah, I’m definitely up for trying it out, even if it feels a bit weird at first with the denser stuff. I just hope I don’t get too frustrated if it doesn’t click right away, ya know?

It's completely normal to feel a bit frustrated if it doesn't work out right away, but remember that it's all part of the learning process. You might want to try breaking down the technical material into smaller chunks and building a story around each section. This could make it feel less overwhelming and more manageable.
Got it, breaking it down into smaller bits sounds like a solid plan to ease into it. I’ll give that a go and see if it helps keep the frustration in check while I’m figuring this out.
Hey, I’m feeling a bit better about tackling this now with that approach. Do you think we could check in next time about how it’s going, just to make sure I’m on the right track?

{{"reasoning": "The session addressed strategies to tackle academic reading challenges, and the client expressed willingness to try them. A follow-up was planned to review progress, indicating no immediate closure invitation.","determination": "continue"}}
Yeah, I’d really appreciate touching base next session to see if this method is working for me. It’d help to know I’ve got some backup if I’m still struggling with it.

{ "reasoning": "The client and therapist have discussed detailed strategies for managing academic reading difficulties, and the client has acknowledged a willingness to try these. However, the client requested a follow-up to review progress.", "determination": "continue" }

therapist: Absolutely, I’m glad to hear you’re feeling a bit more confident about this approach. Let’s definitely check in next session to see how it’s working for you and make any tweaks if needed.

client: Thanks, I’m relieved to know we can revisit this. It just feels good to have a plan and some support lined up.

therapist: I'm glad you feel that way. Before we wrap up, is there anything else on your mind you'd like to touch on today?

client: Nah, I think I’m good for now. Just wanna focus on getting started with this plan and see how it plays out.

concern:
TW: self harm 

I am a 5th year in college who is non-traditional student aged. I was previously academically dismissed and worked so hard to get back into my college and I did! The community college classes I took in the time between was so easy and I didn’t really learn to cultivate better habits as I was able to quickly do work and still get As, which felt good, but not the same at a 4 year college. I have been diagnosed with ADHD/ anxiety/ depression since the 5th grade and didn’t start utilizing accommodations until high school. Used them and did great. College is another story as I started to having to advocate for myself and thought all of my negative symptoms were how everyone felt and who I was. I never saw those things as barriers, but as I have gotten older, the dots have started clicking. I have been embarrassed to use my accommodations until this year because past friends made comments that it’s unfair and I took those to heart. The academic resource center purged my files upon my dismissal so it’s been a mess trying to get the correct documentation and my doctor only sent in the documentation last week even though I was asking for months. I am very frustrated as I’ve been falling behind due to my mental health rapidly declining this semester upon starting a new medication that made everything worse: insomnia, more anxiety, not taking care of myself, thoughts of unaliving myself, and started c*tting myself for a few weeks. I started to make the connection that it was my new med I started and then cut it cold Turkey and have felt better, but I’m still in a disassociative state making functioning hard. I am scared to disclose all of this as I can’t afford to medically withdraw and am supposed to graduate in the spring. I would appreciate any advice for how to handle this

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there! I'm so glad you're here today. I want to assure you that you're in a safe and supportive space, and I'm all ears to hear whatever you'd like to share with me. Is there something specific you'd like to talk about, or perhaps you'd just like to explore your thoughts and feelings? I'm here to listen and help in any way I can.
Hey, thanks for being here. I’m just feeling really overwhelmed with everything going on, especially with school and my mental health, and I’m not sure where to even start.
It's completely understandable to feel that way, and I'm so glad you're reaching out for support. Can you tell me more about what's been going on at school and with your mental health?
Hey, yeah, I can try to break it down a bit. It’s just been a rough semester with classes piling up and my headspace being all over the place, and I’m struggling to keep up.

That sounds like a lot to handle all at once, and it's no wonder you're feeling overwhelmed. It's great that you're trying to break it down, and I'm here to listen and help you sort through it. Is there anything specific that's been causing you the most stress, or is it more of a general sense of being overwhelmed?
Hey, it’s kinda both, I guess. Like, the workload is insane, but it’s also just my mental state making everything feel ten times harder, and I’m scared I’m gonna crash again.

It's clear that you're dealing with a lot, and it's understandable that your mental health is playing a big role in how you're experiencing this stress. Can you tell me a bit more about what you mean by "crash again"?

Hey, yeah, I mean like just completely falling apart, you know, like I did before when I got academically dismissed. I’m terrified of losing everything I’ve worked so hard for again because I can’t get a grip on things.

I can hear the fear and frustration in your words, and I understand that this experience of potentially repeating past patterns is weighing heavily on you. It takes a lot of courage to share these fears and to recognize the connection between your mental state and your academic struggles. I want to acknowledge the hard work and progress you've made so far in getting back on track. Can you tell me more about what helped you recover the last time you "crashed," and how you've been coping with things this time around?

Hey, thanks for recognizing that, it means a lot. Last time, I kinda just threw myself into community college and focused on small wins to build myself back up, but this time, I’m struggling to find that same drive and just feel stuck.

It's really admirable that you were able to rebuild yourself after such a difficult experience, and it's understandable that finding that drive again might feel like an uphill battle. What do you think might help reignite that spark this time around, or are there any small steps you could take to start feeling more in control?

Hey, honestly, I’m not even sure what could help right now, everything feels so overwhelming. I guess maybe breaking stuff down into smaller bits again, but I’m just so tired and scared I won’t be able to keep up even with that.

I hear the exhaustion and fear in your voice, and it’s okay to feel overwhelmed right now. What if we paused and took a moment to acknowledge the fact that you’re still here, still trying, and still open to finding a way forward? That in itself shows resilience and courage. Can you tell me more about what “feeling stuck” means to you, or what small step might feel even slightly doable in this moment?

Hey, thanks for saying that, it’s kinda reassuring to hear I’m still showing some resilience even when I don’t feel it. I guess “feeling stuck” is like, I want to move forward, but my brain just won’t let me—like I’m frozen and can’t even start the smallest thing without panicking about failing again. A small step, maybe just making a list of what I need to do, but even that feels like a lot sometimes. What do you think I could do to make starting stuff feel less scary?

I really appreciate you sharing this with me. It sounds like starting even the smallest tasks feels daunting right now, but the fact that you mentioned making a list of what you need to do shows that you're still trying to find a way forward. What if we reframed that first step as not about doing the tasks themselves, but simply about naming them? Would that feel any less scary?

Hey, thanks for suggesting that, it does kinda feel a bit less intimidating to just name the tasks instead of jumping straight into doing them. I think I could maybe handle just writing them out without the pressure of starting right away—do you think that could help me build some momentum or at least trick my brain into not freaking out as much?

It's wonderful that you're finding ways to make things feel more manageable! Reframing that first step as simply naming tasks could indeed help reduce the pressure and create a sense of momentum. It's also a great way to acknowledge that progress, no matter how small, is still progress. Remember, every task you write down is a step forward, even if it's just on paper for now.

Hey, thanks for the encouragement, it really helps to hear that even small stuff like writing things down counts as progress. I’m gonna try just listing out a couple things tonight and see if it eases up some of the panic—maybe it’ll help me feel a little more in control.

That’s a really thoughtful approach, and I’m glad you’re giving yourself permission to start small. How about we also brainstorm a few strategies you can use if the panic does creep in while you’re listing tasks? Maybe something like taking a few deep breaths, stepping away for a moment, or reminding yourself that this is just a list and not a commitment to act yet?

Hey, I appreciate you thinking ahead about ways to handle the panic if it shows up. I think taking a few deep breaths or stepping away for a bit could work—maybe I’ll try that if I start feeling overwhelmed while making the list. What do you think about adding something like listening to a calming song or something to help reset my head if I need a break?

That sounds like a fantastic idea! Adding a calming song to your toolkit could be a really effective way to reset your mind and give yourself a moment to breathe. It’s all about creating a supportive environment for yourself, and it’s great that you’re thinking about what works best for you.

Hey, thanks for affirming that, I’m glad to hear a calming song could be a good addition. I’ll try to pick one or two songs that usually help me chill out and keep them handy for when I’m working on my list.

That’s a great plan, and I’m excited you’re creating a personalized toolkit to support yourself. How do you feel about picking one or two songs to test out tonight, and we can revisit how it worked for you next time we talk?

Hey, I’m totally down to pick a couple of songs to test out tonight, I think it could really help take the edge off. I’ll let you know how it goes when we chat next, I’m curious to see if it makes a difference.

therapist: I’m glad you’re open to trying this out, and I’m looking forward to hearing how it feels for you. Is there anything else on your mind before we wrap up today?

client: Hey, thanks for checking in. I think I’m good for now, just gonna focus on this plan and see how it plays out.

concern:
So basically I got caught in a room with a bunch of alcohol and we were all underage. (18) It wasn't even my room either it was some dumbasses room and these dudes started fighting in there. Long story short the RA's were called and I was caught, and put on probation. Now if I get caught again I'll probably be kicked out of here or worse. 

None of my other friends have probation like me so they're just living their lives care free, while I'm paranoid to even go to another person's place. I don't know I feel like none of this was even deserved on my part, and even tonight I was invited to do drinking games with some other friends. Should I even go? I'm so nervous and upset. Probation lasts a whole year man... GOD

It sounds like you’re carrying a lot of weight on your shoulders right now, and that constant pressure to be so cautious must feel exhausting. Can you tell me a bit more about what’s been making you feel that way?
Client: Yeah, it’s just like I’m always second-guessing every move I make, worried I’ll mess up again. I feel so stuck while everyone else seems to be just fine, and it’s really getting to me.

It sounds like you’re caught in a loop of uncertainty and self-doubt, and that feeling of being stuck must be incredibly frustrating. Can you tell me more about what it’s like to feel like you’re the only one struggling, while others seem to be moving forward?

Client: Man, it’s just rough seeing everyone else chilling and having fun, like they don’t have a care in the world, while I’m over here stressing about every little thing. I feel like I’m missing out, and it’s hard not to be bitter or just wanna say screw it sometimes, you know?

It's understandable that you'd feel that way, and it's really brave of you to share those feelings. It sounds like you're struggling with a lot of pressure and frustration, and it's okay to feel overwhelmed. I'm here to listen and support you without judgment.

Client: Thanks, I really appreciate that. It just sucks feeling like I’m on a totally different page than everyone else, and I’m not even sure how to deal with it without just shutting myself off completely, you know?

It’s completely valid to feel like you’re on a different wavelength than others, and it takes a lot of courage to share those feelings. It sounds like you’re struggling with the pressure to keep up and the fear of being different, and it’s okay to feel overwhelmed. What would it look like for you to take a step back and prioritize your own well-being, even if that means doing things differently than others?

Client: Honestly, I’m not even sure what that would look like. Like, I guess I could just focus on my own stuff, maybe stick to quieter hangouts or just chill by myself more, but I’m scared I’ll end up feeling even more isolated, you know?

It sounds like you're caught between a desire to fit in and the fear of being isolated if you take a step back. That must be a really difficult place to be, especially when it feels like others are moving forward while you're stuck. What do you think might be the first small step you could take to prioritize your well-being, even if it's just a tiny change?

Client: I don’t know, maybe just saying no to stuff that feels risky, like skipping out on parties for now, even if it sucks to miss out. I guess I could try finding other ways to hang with friends, like grabbing food or watching a movie instead, but I’m still worried I’ll feel left out or like I’m not really part of things, you know?

It's completely understandable to feel torn between wanting to connect with others and needing to take care of yourself. It sounds like you're already thinking of some small steps you could take, like saying no to certain situations and finding alternative ways to spend time with friends. Would you be open to exploring some of those options further and seeing how they might help you feel more in control and less overwhelmed?

Client: Yeah, I think I’m open to trying that out, even if it feels kinda weird to change things up. I just hope I can still feel like I’m part of the group without always being in the middle of the risky stuff, you know?

That's a great point, and it's natural to want to maintain connections while also taking care of yourself. What if we brainstormed a few low-pressure social activities that might help you stay connected with your friends without feeling overwhelmed?

Client: For sure, I’d be down to brainstorm some ideas. Like, maybe just hitting up a coffee shop or doing something chill like a game night, but I’m still kinda nervous about how to bring it up without sounding lame or whatever, you know?

It sounds like you're already coming up with some great ideas, like coffee shops and game nights, that could help you stay connected with your friends while taking care of yourself. How about we think of a few ways you could suggest these activities without feeling awkward or worried about how your friends will react?
Client: Yeah, that’d be really helpful. I’m just worried they might think I’m being boring or overreacting, so figuring out how to say it without sounding like a buzzkill would be awesome, you know?

One approach could be to frame your suggestions as something you're personally excited to try, like, ""Hey, I found this awesome board game cafe downtown – we should check it out!"" or ""I've been craving some good coffee and conversation, wanna hit up that new spot?"" This way, you're not directly addressing your concerns, but still inviting them to join you in a different kind of activity. Another idea is to start with a question, like, ""What if we tried something a little different this weekend?"" – this opens up the conversation without immediately suggesting a specific activity.

Client: Yo, I like those ideas, especially the one about just saying I’m hyped to try something new. I think I could pull that off without it feeling too weird, but I’m still kinda stressing about if they push back or try to drag me into the usual stuff, you know?

It's totally normal to feel nervous about how your friends will react. How about we think of some responses you could use if they do push back or suggest the usual activities? For example, you could say something like, ""I'm really excited to try this new thing, but I'm also open to hearing your ideas! What if we do this today and save the other plans for another time?""

Client: Yeah, that sounds like a solid way to handle it without shutting them down completely. I guess I’m just worried that if they keep pushing, I’ll cave or feel like I’m missing out, you know, FOMO is real, and I don’t wanna be the odd one out all the time.

Therapist: I get that FOMO can be tough, especially when you’re trying to balance your needs with staying connected. How about we brainstorm a couple of ways to remind yourself why you’re making these choices, and maybe even a quick phrase or mantra to keep your confidence up when you feel that pressure?

Client: Yeah, I’d really appreciate that. It’d be cool to have something to lean on when I start second-guessing myself, especially in the moment when it’s hard to think straight.

Therapist: Great, let’s come up with a simple phrase or reminder that feels authentic to you, like, “I’m choosing what’s best for me right now,” or something that resonates with your goals. We can also think of a quick mental checklist to ground yourself if you feel that pressure creeping in.

Client: That sounds super helpful. Maybe something short like “I’ve got this” could work—something I can just repeat to myself without overthinking it, you know?

Therapist: Absolutely, "I’ve got this" is a great choice—simple and empowering. Let’s also pair it with a quick mental note, like reminding yourself of one positive outcome you’re aiming for, to keep you focused when the doubt kicks in.

Client: Cool, I think tying it to a specific reason, like feeling better about my choices, could really help me stay grounded. I’m feeling a bit more confident already just talking this out, so thanks for that.

Therapist: I'm glad you're feeling a bit more confident—that’s a great step forward. Is there anything else on your mind before we wrap up today?

Client: Nah, I think I’m good for now. Just gonna keep practicing this stuff and see how it goes, ya know? Thanks for the help today.

concern:
Hello all, after a gap year I've been at my best with my education. In high school I had a 1.9GPA and figured my shit out at my community college 

Here I've had GPAs of 3.3, 3.39, and now 3.5 and honor roll last Semester. 

This semester though I've been so depressed just thinking about it. Like all these assignments, tests, etc. Is all getting exhausting, probably because the way I work myself to try and do the best I can. 

I'm just extremely stressed already on the first day.

Anyone else feel like they are wore down?

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome! I'm glad you're here. Please feel free to share whatever's on your mind today - whether it's a specific challenge, a recurring thought, or just something you'd like to explore. I'm here to listen and support you.
Hey, thanks for being here. I’m just feeling really overwhelmed with school already, even though it’s just the start of the semester, and I’m struggling to keep up with my own expectations.

It sounds like you're already putting a lot of pressure on yourself, and that can be really tough. Can you tell me more about what's making you feel overwhelmed, and what those expectations of yours look like?
client: Yeah, I just feel like I’m constantly pushing myself to do better, and it’s draining me. Like, I’ve come so far, but I’m scared I’ll slip up if I don’t keep grinding, you know?

It's clear that you have high standards for yourself, and it sounds like that drive has helped you get where you are today. But it also sounds like that pressure is taking a toll on you. Can you tell me more about what it feels like when you're afraid of slipping up, and what you think might happen if you do?

Hey, yeah, it’s like this constant knot in my stomach, you know, just worrying that if I let up even a little, everything I’ve worked for could fall apart. I keep thinking I’ll go back to how I was in high school, messing up and feeling like a failure again.

It sounds like you've come a long way since high school, but that fear of slipping up is still lingering. It’s completely understandable to want to protect what you've worked so hard for. What do you think might happen if you allowed yourself to ease up just a bit, and what would that mean for your confidence and sense of control?

Hey, I don’t know, I guess I’m just scared that if I ease up, I’ll lose my momentum and start failing again. It feels like I need to keep pushing hard to prove I’m not that person from high school anymore, you know?

It's clear that you've put in a lot of effort to become the person you are today, and it makes sense that you're worried about slipping back into old patterns. But what if you could find a balance between keeping your momentum and also taking care of yourself? What would that look like for you, and what might happen if you gave yourself permission to ease up just a bit?

Hey, I think finding a balance sounds nice, but I’m not even sure what that would look like, you know? I guess I’d maybe cut back on overthinking every assignment, but I’m worried I’d just feel guilty or like I’m slacking if I do that.

It’s understandable to feel uncertain about finding a balance, especially when the fear of slipping up is so strong. What if we explored what small changes might help you ease up without feeling guilty, like setting aside specific times to review assignments instead of overthinking them constantly?

Hey, I think that could work, like setting specific times to focus on stuff instead of letting it take over my whole day. I’m just kinda nervous that I might still feel like I’m not doing enough, you know?

You’re doing a great job of considering small, manageable changes that can help you find balance without sacrificing your progress. It’s important to remember that taking care of yourself is a form of self-respect, not a sign of slacking. How might you remind yourself of this when those guilty feelings pop up?

Hey, I guess I could try telling myself that taking breaks or setting limits is actually helping me stay on track, not derailing me. It’s just hard to believe that sometimes, you know, when I’ve got this voice in my head saying I gotta keep going no matter what.

It’s amazing how you’re already coming up with ways to reframe your thoughts and build self-compassion. What if we brainstormed some specific phrases or mantras that could help you counteract that voice when it shows up? Maybe even a short routine to reset your mindset when you notice the guilt creeping in?

Hey, I think having some go-to phrases or a little routine could really help quiet that nagging voice, you know? I’m just not sure what would feel right to say or do in those moments—could we maybe throw around some ideas together?

Absolutely, we can definitely explore some ideas together! One approach might be to start by identifying the specific situations or thoughts that tend to trigger your guilt, and then brainstorming personalized phrases or actions that feel authentic and supportive to you. What if we tried creating a short list of phrases that focus on self-compassion and reframing the idea of balance, like ""I’m choosing to take care of myself so I can stay focused and productive"" or ""Setting limits helps me maintain my energy and motivation""?

Hey, I like the sound of those phrases, especially the one about choosing to take care of myself—it feels kinda grounding, you know? Could we maybe tweak them a bit or come up with a couple more that hit home for me when I’m stuck in that guilt spiral?

Therapist: Of course, we can absolutely tweak those phrases and brainstorm a few more that resonate with you personally. Let’s start by focusing on what feels most supportive to you in those tough moments—maybe something that reminds you of your strength or long-term goals. How about something like, "I’m building strength by pacing myself" or "Balance is my key to lasting success"? What do you think of those, or do you have other ideas that might feel even more personal?

Client: Hey, I really like the one about balance being the key to success—it kinda reminds me why I’m trying to slow down in the first place. Maybe we could also try something like, "I’m allowed to rest and still be enough," since I sometimes feel like I’m not doing enough, you know?

Therapist: I’m glad the idea of balance resonates with you, and I love the phrase you came up with about being allowed to rest and still be enough—it’s so powerful and personal. Let’s keep that one in your toolkit and maybe even write it down somewhere you can see it often. How do you feel about pairing it with a small action, like taking a deep breath or stepping away for a minute, to help reinforce it when that feeling of not doing enough creeps in?

Client: Hey, pairing it with something like a deep breath or a quick step away sounds doable and kinda calming, honestly. I think having that little combo could really help me reset when I’m feeling off, you know?

Therapist: I’m so glad that feels like a good fit for you. Let’s make sure you’ve got this combo written down or saved somewhere handy so you can turn to it when you need it. Before we wrap up, is there anything else on your mind that you’d like to touch on or any other ideas you want to explore together?

Client: Hey, I think I’m good for now—having this phrase and little reset plan feels like a solid step forward. Thanks for helping me work through this, I’m feeling a bit more hopeful about managing those rough moments.
