concern:
I’m 25, and will be graduating this year (my last term this fall). I will be 26 by then.

I dropped out of uni. Immigrated as a student when I was 20. Worked a few part time jobs and took a few summer off to work and did a few internships, just to get myself through college.

I feel beyond shit for being way too behind everyone I know. People in my uni are mostly around 18-21 and I just feel embarrassed sometime. I mean, I know “it’s not a race” but I get severe axiety sometime just to think about it.

Anyone graduated in their mid-late 20s, how did you get over overthinking and how is life going?

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there! I'm so glad you've decided to join me today. Please, take your time and share with me whatever's been on your mind. Whether it's a specific concern or just a general feeling, I'm here to listen and support you in any way I can.
Hey, thanks for having me. I’ve just been feeling really overwhelmed lately with graduating later than most people I know, and it’s messing with my head a bit.
I'm sorry to hear that. It sounds like you've been feeling really stuck lately. Can you tell me a bit more about how this has been affecting you?

Yeah, it’s just this constant weight, you know, like I’m always comparing myself to others who seem so much further ahead. It makes me anxious and kinda embarrassed, especially being around younger students who are on a different timeline.

I can imagine how tough that must be, feeling like you're always looking over your shoulder and comparing yourself to others. It sounds like you're carrying around a lot of pressure and maybe even some shame. Can you tell me more about what it's like to feel embarrassed around younger students?

client: Yeah, it’s like I stick out, you know, being older and still figuring stuff out while they’re just breezing through on the “normal” track. I keep thinking they’re judging me or wondering why I’m still here, even though I know that’s probably just in my head.

It sounds like you're holding yourself to a pretty high standard and feeling like you don't quite measure up. It's interesting that you mention this being in your head, because that makes me wonder what it would be like if you could start being a little kinder to yourself.

Yeah, I get that, but being kinder to myself feels so hard when I’m constantly reminded I’m not where I “should” be. I just wish I could stop obsessing over the age thing and focus on what I’ve actually done to get here.

So, like, how do I even start to shift my thinking on this? I mean, I know I’ve worked hard, but it’s tough to feel proud when I keep seeing everyone else moving faster.

It's really brave of you to be open about how tough this has been. It sounds like you're carrying a lot of self-doubt, but I'm curious—have you ever stopped to think about what your life might look like if you were able to shift your focus from comparison to your own progress? Maybe we could explore what that could feel like for you.

Honestly, I haven’t really thought about it that way, like focusing just on my own stuff without the constant comparison. It sounds nice, but I’m not even sure where to begin with that—can we maybe break it down or something?

Let's take a moment to imagine that life without the constant comparison. How might it feel to focus on your own progress and celebrate your hard work? Perhaps we can start by exploring the values and strengths that brought you to this point, and how those can guide your journey forward.

client: That sounds kinda relieving, honestly, to just think about my own path without the weight of everyone else’s timeline. Can we, like, dig into how I can actually start seeing my hard work as something to be proud of, instead of just a reminder of how long it took?

That's a great place to start—let's explore those values and strengths that have gotten you to this point. Maybe we can look at some specific moments where your hard work paid off, even if it didn't look exactly how you imagined. What comes to mind when you think of a time when your efforts really made a difference, no matter how small?

concern:
hi all! i have accommodations at my college and if you don’t know about those you should!! i have a documented disability (mental health related) that states i need a few extra steps to make college life easier.



anyways, in order to put these into place you must visit your professor and discuss them with a letter from the coordinator and have them sign it, which i have done for all my classes except this one. last week was my first week back but i’m recovering from covid and the flu so i couldn’t attend but have went back yesterday. i attempted to find my professors office last week but had to go home from almost passing out and yesterday despite the posted hours, he wasn’t available in his office. so now i’m left with the biggest issue ever, how do i handle my preferential seating?!



usually i sit closest to the door because i tend to leave the class at times for movement or if something goes bad in my head, but yesterday made me realize i can’t just sit wherever.



i had talked to my professor before class and he let me know to sit wherever i need to so i did but i had a girl tell me i was in her spot and needed to move. there’s no assignees seating and i had gotten the go ahead from my prof but this still caught me off guard as i’m a very nervous person. i cant imagine telling someone they’re in my spot, and didn’t even do that in high school. there was a spot one over from me, and she ended up sitting in it anyways. i did let her know i have accommodations to sit where i need to and she walked away, but now i can’t say that because i haven’t talked to the prof.



we’re advised to only talk about accommodations outside of class and during office hours, but i’m getting extremely anxious for my class in two hours and my teacher only has office hours after. should i email? i know im not supposed to email about this but i’m not sure what to do when i’m told i’m in someone’s spot and i’m in the spot that works best for me. any advice? am i being dramatic? i want to say let’s all be adults but i’m the one refusing to get up from someone’s else’s spot lol

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm here to listen and support you in any way I can. Please feel free to share whatever's on your mind or any concerns you might have, and I'll do my best to help you navigate through them.
Thanks for being here. I’m just really stressed about a situation with my class seating and accommodations, and I’m not sure how to handle it without making things worse.
That sounds really overwhelming. Can you tell me more about what's going on with your class seating and accommodations? I'm here to listen and help however I can.

Thanks, I appreciate that. I’m just really worried about not having my accommodations set up yet with one of my professors, and it’s causing some awkward moments in class that are making me super anxious.

It sounds like the uncertainty around your accommodations is really weighing on you, and those awkward moments in class can feel especially stressful. How have you been coping with the anxiety so far, and is there anything specific about the situation that's been on your mind lately?

Thanks for understanding how heavy this feels. I’ve been trying to just breathe through the anxiety, but honestly, I keep replaying those awkward interactions in my head, especially worrying about what others might think if I have to explain myself again.

It's completely understandable that those moments would replay in your mind and feel so heavy. It sounds like you're carrying a lot of self-consciousness and worry about how others might perceive you. Would it be helpful to explore ways to ease that self-doubt and perhaps reframe how you see these interactions?
Yeah, I’d really appreciate that. I’m just so stuck on feeling like I’m causing a problem or looking weird, and I’d love some help figuring out how to not let that take over my head so much.

It’s clear that you’re already taking steps by recognizing how these thoughts affect you, and wanting to make a change. Can we try to imagine how things might feel differently if you could shift that inner dialogue, even just a little?
Yeah, I’d love to try that. I just feel like my brain gets stuck on the worst-case scenarios, and I’m not sure how to flip the script when I’m in the middle of overthinking everything.

I can see how those worst-case scenarios play on a loop in your mind, but maybe we can work on introducing a new soundtrack, one that reminds you of your strengths and resilience. What would it feel like to have a little more confidence in your ability to navigate these moments, even if it starts small?

Honestly, that sounds really nice, even if it feels kinda out of reach right now. I just wanna believe I can handle these situations without spiraling, ya know, but I’m not sure where to even start with building that confidence.

It's great that you're open to imagining that shift, even if it feels far away right now. Let's explore what small steps could start building that confidence, maybe starting with something that feels manageable, like pausing to take a breath before spiraling into worst-case scenarios?

Yeah, that sounds doable, like just taking a second to breathe could maybe stop my head from running wild. I’m willing to give it a shot, even if I’m a bit skeptical about how much it’ll help when I’m already freaking out.

You're already taking a powerful step by being open to trying, even with some skepticism. And you're right, that moment of pause might seem small, but it can be the first crack in that loop of worst-case scenarios. Imagine what it could feel like to have even a little more space between those spiraling thoughts and your response. What would that small breath of space give you, in those moments when you're already freaking out?

I think having even a tiny bit of space there would feel like a relief, like I’m not totally trapped by my thoughts. It’d probably give me a chance to remind myself that I’ve got this, even if it’s just for a second before the anxiety kicks back in.

You’re starting to visualize that space, even if it’s fleeting at first. What if we built on that momentary relief by adding a quick mental anchor, like silently repeating a short phrase that grounds you in that confidence, right after you take that breath?

That sounds like it could help, like having something to hold onto when my mind’s all over the place. What kinda phrase should I use, though, ‘cause I’m not sure what would feel right or stick with me when I’m in that anxious mess?

That's a great question, and it’s important that the phrase feels personal and meaningful to you. What if you thought about something simple and grounding, like a phrase that reminds you of your strength, like “I’ve got this,” or “I’m okay right now”? Or maybe a phrase that’s connected to a positive memory or emotion, like a favorite song lyric or a mantra that brings you peace? The key is to find something that resonates with you and feels like a gentle reminder of your inner strength, especially in those anxious moments.

I like the idea of keeping it simple, like “I’ve got this” could work since it’s short and I’ve kinda thought that before when I push through tough stuff. Do you think it’s okay if I change it up sometimes if something else feels better in the moment, or should I stick to one thing?

It's completely okay to adapt your phrase as needed—what matters most is that it feels empowering in the moment. If "I've got this" becomes your go-to but you occasionally find another phrase resonates more, that's part of the process. You're not locked into one option, just like your confidence can grow in different ways. How does that flexibility sound to you?

That flexibility sounds really good, honestly, like I’m not boxed into one way of handling things. I guess I’m just worried I might overthink it in the moment and forget what to say to myself—does that happen a lot, or am I stressing too much about this?

That's a common concern, and it's not too much to worry about—many people find that the phrase becomes more automatic with practice, especially when paired with that intentional breath. You might even jot down a few options to keep somewhere handy, like a note in your phone, to refer to if your mind goes blank in the moment.

That’s a good idea, having a few phrases in my phone as a backup feels like a safety net. I’m just wondering, do you think practicing this outside of stressful moments, like when I’m calm, could help it stick better when I really need it?

Yeah: I think that’s a smart approach, and practicing when you’re calm can definitely help it feel more natural during tougher times. If it’s okay, I’d like to try that out and see how it feels over the next week or so.

Just curious, do you think there’s anything else I should be focusing on alongside this to help with the anxiety, or should I just start with this for now?

I’m glad you’re open to trying this out over the next week. I guess I’m just wondering if there’s anything else I should be pairing with this to keep the anxiety in check, or if I should just focus on getting comfortable with this first?

{{"reasoning": "The session has not concluded with a summary of goals or a next-step plan, and there is no invitation for closure. The client is still seeking guidance on additional strategies.", "determination": "continue"}}

I’m glad to hear you’re on board with trying this out. I guess I’m just curious if there’s anything else I should be working on alongside this to help manage the anxiety, or if sticking with this for now is the best starting point?

concern:
I want to post this because I've been feeling this way for a while and wanted to know if others have experienced this. I'm (20M) an Arab international student in Los Angeled, and I can't help but wonder if there's a huge disconnect between international students and Americans (and other Natives in other countries).

I've been at my particular University for 2 years in person at this point in time, and it feels like when I try to make friends with Americans, they expect to not relate to me and so immediately put up a barrier with me, which makes it difficult to connect with anyone on campus. It sort of feels like they're expecting huge cultural differences, which I don't fully blame them for. Part of it is international students clinging on to each other, and part of it is just expecting to not connect. I would see my other American friends have other people approach them, whereas I would approach people and be dealt with distance and uninterest.

What do you guys think? Have you experienced or witnessed anything along these lines?

dialogue_total.statement: Hey there, I'm so glad you're here! Please feel free to share whatever's on your mind today. I'm all ears and ready to listen to whatever you'd like to talk about.
Hey, thanks for being here to listen. I’ve just been feeling really isolated on campus, like there’s this wall between me and the American students, and I’m not sure how to break through it.
That sounds really tough, and I can imagine how isolating that must feel. Can you tell me more about what's been making you feel like there's this wall between you and the American students?

client: Yeah, it’s like, I try to talk to people and join in on conversations, but I get this vibe that they’re not really interested or they’re just expecting we won’t click because I’m not from here. It’s frustrating because I want to connect, but it feels like there’s already this assumption that we’re too different to get along.

It sounds like you're putting yourself out there and trying to connect, but it's like the other people are already making assumptions about you before you even get a chance to talk. That must be really frustrating, especially when you're trying your best to reach out.

**, yeah, it’s super frustrating because I’m really trying to make an effort, you know? Like, I want to be part of the group, but it just feels like I’m hitting a wall every time, and I don’t know if it’s something I’m doing wrong or if it’s just how they see me from the start.

It sounds like you're feeling caught between trying your best to fit in and feeling like there's this invisible barrier that's keeping you from connecting. That must be really disheartening, especially when you're putting in the effort to reach out and be part of the group.

Yeah, exactly, it’s like no matter how much I try, there’s this barrier I can’t get past. I just keep wondering if I’m missing something, like if there’s a way I’m supposed to act or talk that I’m not getting, or if it’s just always gonna be like this because I’m not from here. I mean, I’ve made a few friends with other international students, but I really want to connect with everyone, you know? It’s kinda draining to keep trying and not see it go anywhere. What do you think I could do to maybe change how this feels or how people react to me?

It's clear how much you care about connecting with others, and I appreciate your willingness to keep trying. I'm curious, what do you think it would mean for you if you could break down that barrier, even a little?

Man, if I could break down that barrier even just a bit, I think it’d feel like a huge weight off my shoulders, you know? Like, I’d finally feel like I belong here, or at least like I’m not just stuck on the outside looking in all the time. It’d probably give me more confidence to keep reaching out, too, instead of always second-guessing myself. What do you think, like, are there specific things I could try to help make that happen, or ways to kinda show people I’m not as different as they might think?

I can see how much breaking down that barrier would mean to you, and it's beautiful that you're still holding onto that hope despite the challenges. It sounds like you already have a good sense of how to start bridging that gap, but maybe we could explore a bit more what that might look like for you, like finding moments or ways to share your unique perspective in a way that feels authentic and might help others see you differently.

Thanks, I really appreciate that. I’m definitely open to figuring out ways to share more of who I am, but honestly, I’m not even sure where to start sometimes, you know? Like, I don’t wanna come off as forcing my background or story on people, but I also feel like if I don’t, they just assume stuff about me. I guess I’m worried about how to bring it up naturally without it feeling awkward or like I’m trying too hard. Got any ideas on how I could do that, maybe in casual convos or group settings?

It sounds like you're already thinking about how to share your perspective in a way that feels natural and authentic, and that's a great place to start. Maybe we could brainstorm some casual ways to bring up your background or story in conversations, like finding common interests or experiences that you can use as a starting point to share a bit about yourself. For example, if someone mentions a favorite food or movie, you could share a similar experience from your culture, or if you're in a group setting and someone asks about your interests, you could mention something about your background that relates to that interest. It's all about finding those moments where you can share a little bit of yourself without feeling like you're forcing it or overexplaining. What do you think?

Thanks for the ideas, I really like the thought of tying my background into stuff like food or movies—those are easy convo starters. I guess I’m just a bit nervous about how people might react, like if they’ll even care or if it’ll just make things weird, but I’m willing to give it a shot and see what happens. What do you think about maybe practicing how I’d bring something like that up, just to get more comfy with it before trying it out for real? I feel like if I could run through a couple scenarios with you, it might help me not overthink it so much when I’m actually talking to someone.

That sounds like a great idea! Let's practice a few scenarios where you could naturally bring up your background in conversations, and I'll help you work through how to approach them in a way that feels comfortable and authentic for you.

Awesome, I’m glad you’re on board with that! I think just running through a couple of casual chats, like maybe talking about a favorite dish from back home or a movie that’s big in my culture, could help me figure out how to word it without feeling like I’m oversharing or making it awkward. I’m kinda excited to try this out, but still a bit nervous about messing it up—any tips on how to keep it light and not overthink while we practice?

It's totally normal to feel a bit nervous when practicing something new, especially when it involves sharing parts of yourself. To keep it light, try focusing on the shared interest or experience rather than the potential reaction, and remember that you can always adjust your approach as you go along. And don't worry about messing up—this is a safe space to try things out, and we'll work through it together.

Cool, that makes sense. I’ll try to just focus on the topic itself, like keeping it about the food or movie, and not stress too much about how it lands. I guess it helps knowing this is a no-pressure zone to mess around with ideas. So, maybe we can start with something simple—like, if someone’s talking about what they ate over the weekend, how would I slide in a mention of a dish from back home without it feeling forced? I’m thinking something like, “Oh, that sounds good, it reminds me of this dish we make a lot where I’m from,” but I don’t know if that sounds too abrupt. What do you think?

That sounds like a great way to start! Adding a personal touch by connecting the dish they mentioned to something familiar from your culture can make it feel natural and inviting. You could even add a bit more by asking them if they’ve tried anything similar, or sharing a fun memory associated with that dish. And if you ever feel unsure, you can always pause and let the conversation flow, then bring it up again when it feels right. Let’s try a quick role-play and see how it feels in action!

Cool, I’m down to try the role-play and see how it goes. I like the idea of adding a little memory or asking if they’ve tried something similar—that feels like a good way to keep the convo going without it being just about me. So, let’s do this—pretend you’re someone I just met at, like, a campus event or something, and we’re chatting about food. I’ll try bringing up a dish from back home and see how it flows. How do you wanna start it off?

Hey, nice to meet you! I had this amazing pasta dish over the weekend with a creamy sauce—totally hit the spot. What about you, had anything good lately?

therapist: That sounds really tough, and I can imagine how isolating that must feel. Can you tell me more about what's been making you feel like there's this wall between you and the American students?
client: client: Yeah, it’s like, I try to talk to people and join in on conversations, but I get this vibe that they’re not really interested or they’re just expecting we won’t click because I’m not from here. It’s frustrating because I want to connect, but it feels like there’s already this assumption that we’re too different to get along.
therapist: It sounds like you're putting yourself out there and trying to connect, but it's like the other people are already making assumptions about you before you even get a chance to talk. That must be really frustrating, especially when you're trying your best to reach out.
client: **, yeah, it’s super frustrating because I’m really trying to make an effort, you know? Like, I want to be part of the group, but it just feels like I’m hitting a wall every time, and I don’t know if it’s something I’m doing wrong or if it’s just how they see me from the start.
therapist: It sounds like you're feeling caught between trying your best to fit in and feeling like there's this invisible barrier that's keeping you from connecting. That must be really disheartening, especially when you're putting in the effort to reach out and be part of the group.
client: Yeah, exactly, it’s like no matter how much I try, there’s this barrier I can’t get past. I just keep wondering if I’m missing something, like if there’s a way I’m supposed to act or talk that I’m not getting, or if it’s just always gonna be like this because I’m not from here. I mean, I’ve made a few friends with other international students, but I really want to connect with everyone, you know? It’s kinda draining to keep trying and not see it go anywhere. What do you think I could do to maybe change how this feels or how people react to me?
therapist: It's clear how much you care about connecting with others, and I appreciate your willingness to keep trying. I'm curious, what do you think it would mean for you if you could break down that barrier, even a little?
client: Man, if I could break down that barrier even just a bit, I think it’d feel like a huge weight off my shoulders, you know? Like, I’d finally feel like I belong here, or at least like I’m not just stuck on the outside looking in all the time. It’d probably give me more confidence to keep reaching out, too, instead of always second-guessing myself. What do you think, like, are there specific things I could try to help make that happen, or ways to kinda show people I’m not as different as they might think?
therapist: I can see how much breaking down that barrier would mean to you, and it's beautiful that you're still holding onto that hope despite the challenges. It sounds like you already have a good sense of how to start bridging that gap, but maybe we could explore a bit more what that might look like for you, like finding moments or ways to share your unique perspective in a way that feels authentic and might help others see you differently.
client: Thanks, I really appreciate that. I’m definitely open to figuring out ways to share more of who I am, but honestly, I’m not even sure where to start sometimes, you know? Like, I don’t wanna come off as forcing my background or story on people, but I also feel like if I don’t, they just assume stuff about me. I guess I’m worried about how to bring it up naturally without it feeling awkward or like I’m trying too hard. Got any ideas on how I could do that, maybe in casual convos or group settings?
therapist: It sounds like you're already thinking about how to share your perspective in a way that feels natural and authentic, and that's a great place to start. Maybe we could brainstorm some casual ways to bring up your background or story in conversations, like finding common interests or experiences that you can use as a starting point to share a bit about yourself. For example, if someone mentions a favorite food or movie, you could share a similar experience from your culture, or if you're in a group setting and someone asks about your interests, you could mention something about your background that relates to that interest. It's all about finding those moments where you can share a little bit of yourself without feeling like you're forcing it or overexplaining. What do you think?
client: Thanks for the ideas, I really like the thought of tying my background into stuff like food or movies—those are easy convo starters. I guess I’m just a bit nervous about how people might react, like if they’ll even care or if it’ll just make things weird, but I’m willing to give it a shot and see what happens. What do you think about maybe practicing how I’d bring something like that up, just to get more comfy with it before trying it out for real? I feel like if I could run through a couple scenarios with you, it might help me not overthink it so much when I’m actually talking to someone.
therapist: That sounds like a great idea! Let's practice a few scenarios where you could naturally bring up your background in conversations, and I'll help you work through how to approach them in a way that feels comfortable and authentic for you.
client: Awesome, I’m glad you’re on board with that! I think just running through a couple of casual chats, like maybe talking about a favorite dish from back home or a movie that’s big in my culture, could help me figure out how to word it without feeling like I’m oversharing or making it awkward. I’m kinda excited to try this out, but still a bit nervous about messing it up—any tips on how to keep it light and not overthink while we practice?
therapist: It's totally normal to feel a bit nervous when practicing something new, especially when it involves sharing parts of yourself. To keep it light, try focusing on the shared interest or experience rather than the potential reaction, and remember that you can always adjust your approach as you go along. And don't worry about messing up—this is a safe space to try things out, and we'll work through it together.

concern:
My friend asked to team up with me on an important course project which I valued very much. The whole course is evaluated totally based on the project. I accepted the invitation because I am actually the dumb one among us. However, in the project, I got mad at him. Whenever we came across problems, he would say he didn't know anything and "sorry, I really can't help you", as if this was my personal project. I talked to him so many times about this, and he was tired of me pushing him to think. Then right before the deadline, when we had trouble meeting the minimum requirements, he said he didn't think we need to meet the requirement, and I shouldn't care so much about the project. I worked for two whole weeks with little sleep before the due date, but still, I didn't get any results for the report in the end. When he said "I am sorry that you didn't get the right results", I almost shouted at him.

I feel awkward now talking to him and disappointed with this collaboration. I don't feel proper to complain to the professor. We are friends and still need to meet on lots of occasions. My complaint can make things more complicated. Is there any way to make myself feel better and let go?

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm here to listen and support you without judgment. Feel free to share anything that's been on your mind lately - I'm all ears.
Hey, thanks for being here. I’ve been really stressed about a recent group project with a friend, and it’s left me feeling pretty frustrated and stuck on how to move forward.
That sounds like a really tough situation to be in. Can you tell me more about what's been causing the frustration with the group project?
Yeah, it’s just been a mess with how things played out between us. I feel let down and kinda upset about the whole experience, and now I’m not even sure how to deal with seeing them around.
It sounds like this situation has really taken a toll on you, and I can understand why you'd feel that way. What was it about the group project that left you feeling let down and upset?

Yeah, it’s just that I put in so much effort and felt like I was carrying the whole thing on my own. It’s really frustrating to feel like I wasn’t supported, and now I’m just stuck with this disappointment hanging over me.

It's completely understandable to feel disappointed and frustrated when you put in so much effort and don't receive the support you were expecting. It's important to acknowledge those feelings and allow yourself to process them. How do you think you can start to move forward from this experience, even if it's just a small step?
Honestly, I’m not even sure where to start with moving forward. I just feel so stuck on this frustration, like I need to find a way to let it go without making things weird with my friend.

It's understandable that you feel stuck in this situation, especially when it involves a friend. It sounds like you're looking for a way to let go of the frustration without damaging your relationship. Maybe you could start by reflecting on what you hope for in your friendship and how this experience might be affecting that vision. What would it look like to move forward in a way that respects both your feelings and the friendship?

I guess I’d like to keep the friendship, but I’m worried this resentment might stick around if I don’t address it somehow. I just don’t know if talking to them about it again will help or make things worse, you know?

That’s a really valid concern, and it’s great that you’re thinking about how to navigate this in a way that respects both your feelings and the friendship. It can be helpful to think about what you hope the conversation with your friend might look like and how you can approach it in a way that feels safe and productive.

Yeah, I get that having a convo could be useful, but I’m just nervous it might turn into another argument or make things even more awkward. I want to clear the air, but I don’t know how to bring it up without sounding like I’m blaming them or dragging up old stuff.

It sounds like you're looking for a way to approach this conversation that feels constructive and respectful. Maybe we can start by exploring what you might say or how you could frame the conversation to help avoid blame or rehashing old issues. What are some key points you'd like to express to your friend that could help you both move forward?

I think I’d really just want to tell them that I felt let down during the project and that it’s been hard for me to shake off that feeling. I’d also wanna say I value our friendship and don’t wanna let this get in the way, but I’m not sure how to word it so it doesn’t sound like I’m pointing fingers, ya know?

I hear that you want to express how you felt and also communicate your care for the friendship. Maybe we could start with a phrase like, ""I wanted to talk about something that's been on my mind because I value our friendship and want us to move forward."" How does that feel? It might be helpful to focus on your feelings and experiences rather than placing blame, and also express your desire to resolve the issue together.

That phrasing feels pretty good, actually, like a gentle way to start without making it seem like an attack. I’m just worried I might get emotional or mess up the words when I’m actually talking to them, ‘cause this whole thing still kinda stings, ya know?

It's completely understandable that this situation still feels tender, and it's great that you're thinking about how to approach the conversation in a way that feels authentic and respectful. Maybe we could also brainstorm some ways to help you feel more grounded and composed during the conversation, like taking a few deep breaths beforehand or even jotting down a few key points to refer to if you need them.
That sounds like a good idea, honestly. I think writing down a couple of things to focus on could help me stay on track and not get too worked up when I’m talking to them.

I, I really appreciate the suggestion to prepare like that—it feels like a solid way to keep myself calm. Do you think practicing what I want to say a few times could also help, or would that make it feel too rehearsed?

I'm glad you like the idea of preparing, and yeah, practicing could definitely be helpful to build confidence. I’m just curious if overdoing it might make me sound stiff or unnatural—what do you think?

concern:
So I currently live with my parents who are gonna retire. They are pretty much kicking me out and I don’t know what to do. I contacted my school about getting into a dorm for spring but I was told I would need an additional $10k after FASFA but I can’t afford that. My parents won’t agree to a parent plus loan and application for scholarships ended before I even got accepted. What do I do?

Edit: to everyone saying to get a job, I am starting one tomorrow but even saving every check will not be enough to cover these expenses not to mention the things I would need to bring into the dorm

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! It's great to have you here today. I'm here to listen and support you in any way I can. Please feel free to share whatever's on your mind or any concerns you might have.
Hey, thanks for being here. I’m just really stressed about my living situation and figuring out how to make things work with school and money.
That sounds like a lot to juggle, and I can understand why you'd feel overwhelmed. What's been the biggest challenge for you lately—school, money, or your living situation?
Hey, I’d say it’s mostly the living situation that’s got me messed up right now. I’m just feeling so stuck, like I’ve got nowhere to go and no way to fix this.
It's tough to feel like you're stuck in a situation with no clear way out. What does ""stuck"" feel like to you, and what are some things that have been holding you back from making a change?

client: Honestly, feeling stuck is like I’m just spinning my wheels, you know, like no matter what I try, I’m not getting anywhere. It’s this constant worry in my head about where I’m gonna live and how I’m gonna pay for stuff.

client: I guess what’s holding me back is not having enough money to cover dorm costs or even basic stuff I’d need if I moved out. And with my parents retiring and kinda pushing me out, I’m just panicking about not having a solid plan.

It sounds like financial constraints and a lack of planning are creating a lot of anxiety for you, and I can see how that would make you feel stuck. I'm curious, what would your ideal living situation look like, and how do you envision your life without this constant worry about money and housing?

Hey, honestly, my ideal situation would just be having a stable place to live, like a dorm or cheap apartment, where I don’t have to stress about being kicked out. And I’d love to not have this money weight on me all the time, just focus on school and not feel like I’m drowning.

That sounds like a really important step forward, envisioning a life without those constant worries. What do you think it would take to start moving towards that stable living situation and reduced financial stress?

Honestly, I think it would take finding some kind of financial help or a cheaper place to stay, but I’m not sure where to even start with that. I just feel like I’ve hit a wall with all the options I’ve looked into so far.

It's understandable to feel overwhelmed when it seems like all the doors you've tried are closed. However, it might be helpful to consider exploring other options or resources that you may not have considered yet. What are some things that you haven't tried yet that could potentially help you find financial assistance or a more affordable living situation?

I guess I haven’t really looked into off-campus housing with roommates to split costs or checked if there are any emergency funds through the school. I’m just kinda lost on how to even approach those things without feeling like I’m begging for help.

It’s completely understandable to feel uncertain about where to start or how to ask for help. Perhaps we could explore some steps together to break down the process of researching off-campus housing options or inquiring about emergency funds through your school. Would you be open to discussing possible ways to approach these options without feeling like you're begging for help?

Yeah, I’d definitely be open to talking about how to approach this stuff without feeling like I’m just asking for handouts. I just need some guidance on how to even start these conversations or where to look without getting overwhelmed all over again.

It sounds like you’re ready to take some concrete steps forward, which is really encouraging! One option could be to start by researching local off-campus housing options that offer roommate matching services, which might help you find a more affordable living situation without having to take on the entire responsibility of finding roommates yourself. Additionally, you could reach out to your school’s financial aid office or student services department to inquire about emergency funds or other forms of assistance that might be available to students in your situation.

Cool, I’m glad to hear there are some specific steps I can take. I’ll try looking into those roommate matching services and reaching out to the financial aid office to see what’s out there for emergency help.
Hey, I really appreciate you laying out those starting points for me. Do you think we could brainstorm a quick way to phrase my questions to the financial aid office so I don’t feel awkward about it?
Sure, I’m glad to help with that. How about we come up with a simple way to ask about emergency funds or assistance that feels natural to you?

concern:
I'm currently a freshman at uni, and I am trying to decide if it would be worth it to live alone.

My two options rn are

1:  Live with one of my friends from HS and one of his friends, but we also need a fourth person that we don't have yet. Around \~800 USD

2: Live by myself. \~950 USD

The location from campus is about the same either way, but I am leaning more toward living by myself. 

Is it lonely living alone or is it nice from your experience?

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session! I'm here to listen and support you in any way I can. Please feel free to share whatever is on your mind or whatever you'd like to talk about. I'm all ears and ready to help.
Hey, thanks for being here. I’ve been kinda stuck on this decision about whether to live alone or with roommates next year, and I’m just not sure what’s the best move for me.

It's totally normal to feel stuck on a decision like that, and it sounds like you're really weighing the pros and cons. Can you tell me a little bit more about what's been making this decision feel so tricky?

Yeah, I guess it’s just hard to know if I’ll feel isolated if I live alone, or if I’ll miss out on the social stuff with roommates. I’m torn between wanting my own space and not wanting to feel lonely, ya know?

So, like, have you worked with other students who’ve had to make this kind of choice? What did they end up doing, or what helped them figure it out?

Yeah, I’ve definitely worked with students who’ve struggled with this decision before. Some of them found that the best way to figure it out was by thinking about what they needed most in that moment—whether it was the comfort of their own space or the camaraderie of roommates. It’s all about understanding what will make you feel most balanced and happy in the long run.

Cool, that makes sense. I guess I’m just trying to figure out if I’ll be okay on my own, or if I’ll end up feeling like I’m missing out on stuff, ya know, like those random late-night talks with roommates or whatever. What do you think I should focus on to really get clear on what I need right now?

One thing that could help is thinking about your current routine and how you'd adapt to either situation. For example, if you enjoy your own space, how would you maintain social connections while living alone? If you value those spontaneous roommate moments, how would you ensure you have enough personal time if you live with others? It's about finding a balance that works for you.

Thanks for the suggestion. I think I do enjoy my own space a lot, but I’m worried I might feel too cut off without people around, ya know, like I’d have to go out of my way to see friends. How do you think I can kinda test out how I’d feel in either situation before I make a final call?

It might help to try out a little experiment, like spending a weekend or a few days in a solo environment to see how it feels, or maybe staying with a friend or family member to gauge what that experience is like. You could also talk to people who have lived alone and with roommates to get a sense of their experiences and what they learned from them.

Got it, that sounds like a solid idea. I think I could maybe spend a few days at home alone when my family’s out or crash with a buddy for a bit to get a feel for both vibes, ya know? What kinda stuff should I pay attention to when I’m testing this out, like specific feelings or whatever?

You might want to pay attention to how you feel emotionally during those days—like, do you feel relaxed and focused when you're alone, or do you start to crave social interaction? On the flip side, when you're staying with friends, do you feel energized by their company, or do you miss having your own space? Also, think about your habits—do you stay productive, or do you end up procrastinating when you're alone? Or when you're with others, do you find yourself getting distracted or overwhelmed? Noticing these little things can help you figure out what really matters to you.

Cool, that’s super helpful to think about. I’ll definitely keep track of how I’m feeling emotionally and if I’m getting stuff done or just zoning out in both setups, ya know, to see what clicks better for me. Is there anything else I should consider, like maybe how this choice might affect other parts of my life, like school or even just my mood overall?

It’s a great idea to think about how this decision might ripple into other areas of your life, like school or your overall mood. Maybe consider how each living situation might influence your study habits, your stress levels, or even your social life outside of home. Also, think about your long-term goals—are you hoping for stability, growth, or something else? Reflecting on these angles could help you feel more confident about which path aligns best with where you’re headed.

Hey, thanks for breaking it down like that. I’ll definitely think about how each option might mess with or help my studies and stress, ya know, and where I wanna be in the long run. Is there a way to kinda weigh all these factors, like, should I make a list or something to see which setup fits better with my goals and daily vibe?

You could definitely try making a list or even just jotting down some notes after each trial period—like a quick pros and cons chart or just free-writing about how each situation made you feel and what worked or didn’t. Trust your gut, though, too. Sometimes the best way to weigh it is to sit with the feelings and see which one feels like it’s pulling you forward more.

Gotcha, I like the idea of jotting stuff down after trying things out, maybe making a quick pros and cons list to get my thoughts straight. I’ll also just kinda sit with how each option feels, ya know, and see which one seems to fit better with where I’m at and where I wanna go. Is there a good way to balance, like, wanting my own space but not totally cutting myself off from people if I do end up living alone?

Absolutely, finding that balance between personal space and social connection is totally doable! You might consider scheduling specific times to connect with friends or family each week—like planning a weekly dinner or coffee meetup. That way, you get your alone time, but also make sure you're staying connected with others. Have you thought about how often you'd want to see people if you were living alone?

Hey, that’s a solid idea to schedule stuff like dinners or coffee to keep in touch with people. I haven’t really thought too much about how often I’d wanna see folks if I’m on my own, but maybe a couple times a week would feel right— just enough to not feel out of the loop, ya know? How do you think I could figure out what’s the right amount of social time for me without it feeling forced or like a chore?

Hey, I’m glad you think that scheduling idea could work, and starting with a couple times a week sounds like a good baseline. Maybe try experimenting with different frequencies over a few weeks and just notice how you feel after each hangout—does it energize you or drain you? That might help clue you in on what feels natural without turning into a burden. So, do you think there’s anything else I should keep in mind while I’m figuring this out?

therapist: Welcome to our session! I'm here to listen and support you in any way I can. Please feel free to share whatever is on your mind or whatever you'd like to talk about. I'm all ears and ready to help.
client: Hey, thanks for being here. I’ve been kinda stuck on this decision about whether to live alone or with roommates next year, and I’m just not sure what’s the best move for me.
therapist: It's totally normal to feel stuck on a decision like that, and it sounds like you're really weighing the pros and cons. Can you tell me a little bit more about what's been making this decision feel so tricky?
client: Yeah, I guess it’s just hard to know if I’ll feel isolated if I live alone, or if I’ll miss out on the social stuff with roommates. I’m torn between wanting my own space and not wanting to feel lonely, ya know?

So, like, have you worked with other students who’ve had to make this kind of choice? What did they end up doing, or what helped them figure it out?
therapist: Yeah, I’ve definitely worked with students who’ve struggled with this decision before. Some of them found that the best way to figure it out was by thinking about what they needed most in that moment—whether it was the comfort of their own space or the camaraderie of roommates. It’s all about understanding what will make you feel most balanced and happy in the long run.
client: Cool, that makes sense. I guess I’m just trying to figure out if I’ll be okay on my own, or if I’ll end up feeling like I’m missing out on stuff, ya know, like those random late-night talks with roommates or whatever. therapist: One thing that could help is thinking about your current routine and how you'd adapt to either situation. For example, if you enjoy your own space, how would you maintain social connections while living alone? If you value those spontaneous roommate moments, how would you ensure you have enough personal time if you live with others? It's about finding a balance that works for you.
client: Thanks for the suggestion. I think I do enjoy my own space a lot, but I’m worried I might feel too cut off without people around, ya know, like I’d have to go out of my way to see friends. How do you think I can kinda test out how I’d feel in either situation before I make a final call?
therapist: It might help to try out a little experiment, like spending a weekend or a few days in a solo environment to see how it feels, or maybe staying with a friend or family member to gauge what that experience is like. You could also talk to people who have lived alone and with roommates to get a sense of their experiences and what they learned from them.
client: Got it, that sounds like a solid idea. I think I could maybe spend a few days at home alone when my family’s out or crash with a buddy for a bit to get a feel for both vibes, ya know? What kinda stuff should I pay attention to when I’m testing this out, like specific feelings or whatever?

concern: I’m a first gen and in my senior year about to graduate and ever since I declared business management as my major, my family “playfully” but halfway seriously talks about all the things they wanna use my degree for. “I wanna start this business, you can help me run it with your fancy business degree” “you can organize xyz, put that business degree to good use” “it’s a good thing we have you here to do abc for us with that business degree otherwise we’d be lost” … at first it really was harmless but after four years it’s just annoying. Anyone else ever experience similar things ???

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome! I'm here to listen and support you. Please feel free to share whatever's on your mind or any concerns you might have.
Thanks for being here. I’ve just been feeling really weighed down by some family expectations lately, and I wanted to talk it out.
That sounds really tough, and I’m glad you reached out. Can you tell me a bit more about what’s been going on with your family?

client: Yeah, for sure. It’s just been a lot of pressure building up over time with their comments about how they expect me to use my degree to help with their ideas and stuff, and it’s starting to get to me more than I thought it would.
It sounds like their expectations have been adding up, and it’s really weighing on you. That must feel frustrating, especially if you’re not sure if their ideas align with your own goals and values.

Yeah, exactly, it’s super frustrating because I feel like I’m being pulled in directions I didn’t even choose for myself. I just want to figure out my own path, you know, without all this extra baggage of what they’re expecting from me.

That's completely understandable, and it's okay to feel this way. It's important to find your own path and not let others define what that looks like for you. Have you thought about how you'd like to approach this situation, or what steps you could take to start moving forward in a way that feels authentic to you?

Yeah, I’ve been thinking about it a little, but I’m not really sure where to start. I guess I just wanna set some boundaries or something, but I don’t know how to bring it up without it turning into a big deal or hurting anyone’s feelings.

That makes sense, and it’s great that you’re thinking about setting boundaries to protect your own path. It might be helpful to start by reflecting on what feels most important to you in this situation and how you could express that to your family in a way that feels respectful but honest.

Yeah, I think figuring out what’s most important to me is a good first step, but I’m kinda nervous about how to even word it to them. I don’t wanna come off like I’m shutting them down completely, just need some space to focus on my own stuff, you know?

It's great that you're aware of the importance of communication and setting boundaries. Have you thought about what you might say to your family to express your need for space while still being respectful?

Yeah, I’ve been mulling it over, but I’m still kinda stuck on how to phrase it without sounding like I’m pushing them away. I just want to make it clear I need to focus on my own goals right now, you know, without it feeling like I’m letting them down.

It sounds like you're balancing a desire to set boundaries and protect your own path with a concern for the feelings of those around you. Perhaps you could start by expressing your love and appreciation for your family, and then explain how focusing on your own goals is important for your personal growth and well-being. This might help them understand that your need for space isn't a rejection of them, but rather a way to honor your own needs and aspirations.

Yeah, I like the idea of starting with something positive, like telling them I appreciate their support and all. I just worry it might still come off wrong, or they might not get why I need this space, especially since they’ve been so excited about my degree for years.

I guess I’m also kinda nervous ‘cause I’ve never really had to set a boundary like this before. Like, I’m used to just going along with stuff to keep the peace, so even thinking about this convo feels kinda heavy. Do you think there’s a way to, I don’t know, ease into it or test the waters a bit before diving into a full-on talk? I just don’t wanna mess it up or make things weird at home.

It sounds like you're worried about how your family will react to your new boundaries. You might want to start with a smaller conversation, like telling one family member how you're feeling. That way, you can practice expressing your needs without feeling overwhelmed. You could also ask yourself what specific changes you want to make and how you can approach them in a way that feels authentic to you.

Yeah, I think starting with just one person could be a good way to dip my toe in without it feeling like a huge deal. I’m just not sure who to pick or how to even bring it up casually without it turning into a whole thing.

I guess I’m also wondering, like, what if they don’t take it well even if it’s just a small convo? I don’t wanna start some family drama right before I graduate, you know, so maybe there’s a way to frame it super lightly or something? I just feel like I’m overthinking this, but I can’t help it.

That's understandable, it's natural to feel apprehensive about initiating such conversations. Perhaps you could consider approaching the family member you feel closest to or who has shown the most understanding in the past. You might start by mentioning how much their support has meant to you and then casually express your desire to focus on your goals, without placing too much emphasis on the boundary itself. This could help ease into the conversation and reduce any potential discomfort. Remember, your well-being and personal growth are important, and setting boundaries is a way to honor that.

Yeah, that makes sense, picking someone I’m super close to could definitely feel less intimidating. I think I’ll try that and just keep it light, like you said, so it doesn’t come off as a big confrontation or anything.

I’m still a little worried though, like, what if even that person doesn’t get it and takes it the wrong way? I just don’t wanna risk messing up a good relationship over this, you know, so do you have any tips on how to handle it if they seem upset or push back?

I get that you’re concerned about preserving the relationship while still being honest about your needs. How about we brainstorm a few ways to respond if they seem upset, like acknowledging their feelings and reassuring them that this isn’t about pulling away from them?

I guess I’m just nervous about even imagining that pushback, since I’ve always tried to avoid conflict. Is there a way to kinda prepare myself mentally for that kind of reaction, so I don’t freeze up or backtrack in the moment?

concern:
A blurb on my situation and why I’m asking this: I’m currently in my school’s business program (includes majors in finance, economics, info sys, marketing, etc) with the aim of graduating with a bachelors in management information systems, however calculus has been a major roadblock for me.   
I barely passed precalculus at a cc the first time I took it, failed calculus at the cc, then had to retake precalculus due to credit issues when transferring but failed it this time, and now I’ll need to take calculus again at a cc, and I have little hope that I’ll pass. I have a deadline to pass that class this next semester and if I don’t I’ll be kicked from the business program and won’t have access to any of the above listed majors. Already the prospects of having a nice info sys job are starting to dim. The only major I can think of that will allow me to not take calculus and graduate in a reasonable time is interdisciplinary studies. My remaining classes until I graduate would be poli sci because why not, I think it’s an interesting subject and there’d be no point to taking my remaining business or finance or information systems classes if I can’t have that major at the end of it.  


..  


Tl;dr I suck at calculus  


So basically what my two questions are: will I be stuck working minimum wage jobs with the degree in the title or is there some hope for a “normal” working-in-an-office job?  
What are some jobs that are open to both business and political science majors (because I’m assuming that’s where I’d most likely be heading with this plan)?

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm here to listen and support you. Please feel free to share whatever thoughts or concerns you have on your mind.

Thanks for being here to talk. I’m just really stressed about my situation with school and failing calculus, and I’m worried about what kind of future I’ll have if I can’t stay in the business program.

Therapist: I can hear how much this is weighing on you, and it’s completely okay to feel stressed about this. Let’s explore your concerns about your future and see what options might be available to you.

Assistant: Yeah, I appreciate that. I’m just kinda lost right now, ya know? Like, if I don’t pass calculus and get kicked outta the business program, I’m thinking of switching to interdisciplinary studies with a focus on poli sci, but I’m scared I’ll end up with no good job options. I just wanna know if there’s any hope for a decent office job or something, and maybe what kinda jobs could mix business and poli sci stuff together.

That’s a really understandable fear, and it’s great that you’re thinking about potential paths. Let’s talk more about what you want in a job, and maybe explore some options that blend business and poli sci.

Cool, I’m glad to dive into that. Honestly, I just want something stable, like a 9-to-5 where I’m not stuck doing minimum wage stuff forever, ya know? I’m not super picky, but I’d love to use some of the business skills I’ve picked up, even if I can’t finish that major, and maybe tie in some of the poli sci interests I’ve got. What do you think could work for me with that mix?

You're clearly passionate about combining your business and political science interests, and it's great that you're thinking about what kind of job would give you the stability and satisfaction you're looking for. Let's explore some options that could bring those two fields together, like working in public policy or government relations for a private company, or even a role in non-profit management that leverages your business skills while allowing you to engage with political issues.

Hey, that actually sounds kinda promising. I hadn’t really thought about stuff like public policy or government relations before, but I can see how my business background could fit in there, even if it’s not a full degree. Non-profit management sounds interesting too, ‘cause I like the idea of doing something meaningful. Do you think I’d need extra training or certs for those kinds of roles, or could I jump in with just a bachelor’s in interdisciplinary studies?

It sounds like you’re really open to exploring these options, and it’s great that you’re thinking about how to bridge your interests in business and political science. Let’s talk more about what you might need to get into these roles, and whether there are any additional certifications or training that could help you stand out in the job market.

Yeah, I’m definitely open to figuring this out. I just wanna know if a bachelor’s in interdisciplinary studies will be enough to get my foot in the door for something like public policy or non-profit work, or if I’m gonna need to go back for more classes or certs. Like, I’m already stressed about the time and money I’ve put into school, so adding more on top of that kinda freaks me out. What do you think—can I make it work with what I’ve got, or should I start looking into extra stuff now?

Your interdisciplinary studies degree is a great foundation, and you can definitely leverage your business and political science background to get into public policy or non-profit work. While additional certifications or training might give you an edge, it's not necessarily a requirement. Let's focus on your strengths and the skills you've developed so far, and we can explore options that align with your current degree.

**Client (me, continuing the conversation):** Hey, that’s reassuring to hear that my degree might be enough to start with. I’m just wondering, like, what specific skills or stuff I should focus on highlighting when I’m applying for jobs in public policy or non-profits, ya know? I’ve got some business coursework under my belt, and I’m taking poli sci classes now, but I’m not super confident about how to sell that to an employer. Got any tips on how I can make myself stand out without extra certs or whatever right away?

You've got a solid foundation with your interdisciplinary studies degree and coursework in business and political science. When applying for jobs in public policy or non-profits, focus on highlighting transferable skills like problem-solving, critical thinking, communication, and collaboration, which you've likely developed through your studies and any extracurricular activities. Consider showcasing specific projects or assignments that demonstrate your understanding of both business and political concepts, and don't be afraid to emphasize your unique perspective as someone who can bridge these two fields.

**Client (me, continuing the conversation):** Thanks, that’s super helpful to think about. I’ve done some group projects in my business classes where we had to analyze data and present solutions, and I’ve written a few papers in poli sci that kinda tied into policy issues, so maybe I can play those up. I’m just a bit nervous about, like, not having a super clear career path or specific job title in mind yet. Do you think it’s okay to just apply to a bunch of stuff in those fields and see what sticks, or should I try to narrow it down more before I start looking?

It’s completely fine to explore a range of opportunities in public policy and non-profits, as it can help you discover what truly resonates with you. By applying to various roles and gaining experience, you’ll gain clarity on your strengths and interests, and can refine your career path over time.

**Client (me, continuing the conversation):** Cool, that takes some pressure off, honestly. I guess I’ll start looking into different roles in those areas, maybe internships or entry-level stuff, just to get a feel for what’s out there. I’m kinda worried about not having much real-world experience yet, though—do you think employers will care about that, or can I make up for it with my coursework and, like, enthusiasm when I interview?

You're not alone in that concern, and many employers understand that new grads often have limited direct experience. While they might look for potential and a strong foundation in relevant coursework, your enthusiasm, eagerness to learn, and any transferable skills you've developed through group projects or assignments can definitely make a positive impression. It's also worth considering highlighting any relevant extracurricular activities or volunteer work that demonstrate your passion for the field, as these can help offset a lack of formal experience.

**Client (me, continuing the conversation):** That makes sense, I appreciate the boost of confidence. I’ve done a little volunteering here and there, like helping out at community events, so maybe I can mention that. I’m just wondering, though, how do I even start finding these entry-level gigs or internships in public policy or non-profits? Like, are there specific websites or resources I should check out, or should I just hit up my school’s career center for help?

You can definitely start by reaching out to your school's career center—they often have valuable resources and connections in the field. Additionally, websites like Idealist, LinkedIn, and even local government or non-profit organization websites can be great places to search for entry-level opportunities. Don't forget to leverage your network by letting friends, family, and professors know you're looking—sometimes the best leads come from personal connections.

**Client (me, continuing the conversation):** Thanks, that’s really helpful to know where to look. I’ll definitely check out the career center and poke around on those websites. I hadn’t thought about asking people I know for leads, so I’ll try mentioning it to a few professors or friends. Do you think it’s cool to just reach out to people on LinkedIn, like, cold message them about opportunities, or does that come off as weird or pushy?

You can definitely reach out to people on LinkedIn, and it's not considered weird or pushy if done thoughtfully. It's a common way to network and explore opportunities in your field. A simple, respectful message expressing your interest in their work and asking if they'd be open to a brief conversation about their experiences or advice can be a great starting point.

**Therapist:** I'm glad you're feeling proactive about reaching out, and yes, messaging on LinkedIn is totally fine as long as you keep it professional and genuine. Just make sure to personalize your message, mention something specific about their profile or work, and keep it brief to show you respect their time.

**Client (me, continuing the conversation):** Got it, that’s a relief to hear. I’ll make sure to keep it short and sweet, maybe mention something cool from their profile so it doesn’t sound like a generic copy-paste. I’m kinda nervous about putting myself out there like that, though—do you have any tips on how to not sound, like, super awkward or desperate when I message them?

**Therapist:** Absolutely, it’s normal to feel nervous about reaching out. A good tip is to focus on curiosity—frame your message as wanting to learn from their experience rather than asking for a job outright, and let your genuine interest in their work shine through.

**Client (me, continuing the conversation):** Okay, that makes sense, just focusing on learning from them instead of seeming like I’m begging for something. Thanks for the advice—I think I’ll give it a shot and see how it goes.

A simple, respectful message expressing your interest in their work and asking if they'd be open to a brief conversation about their experiences or advice can be a great starting point.
