concern: I’m feeling nervous about college and debating if i’ve picked the right one. I’m already registered for classes and I have my dorm room/roomate all set but I can’t help but feel nervous. Does/Did anyone feel this way? I’m very introverted and I feel like I won’t be able to make friends because I’m just awkward.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there! I'm really glad you've reached out for support. Please take your time to share whatever's been on your mind or weighing on your heart—I'm here to listen and help in any way I can. 💚
Hey, thanks for being here. I’m just feeling super nervous about starting college and whether I made the right choice, you know?

That sounds really tough. It’s totally normal to feel nervous when starting something new, especially something as big as college. I can imagine you’re probably feeling a bit unsure about whether you made the right decision. It’s okay to feel that way, and it doesn’t mean that you didn’t make a good choice. It just means you’re human, and you care about your future.
Yeah, exactly, I just keep second-guessing myself even though everything’s already set up. It’s like I’m worried I won’t fit in or something, and I don’t know how to shake that feeling.

That's a really valid concern. It’s natural to worry about fitting in, especially when you’re stepping into a new environment. Can you tell me more about what’s making you feel that way? What are some of the things that come to mind when you think about not fitting in?

Hey, yeah, I guess it’s just that I’m super introverted and kinda awkward when it comes to meeting new people. I keep picturing myself just standing there not knowing what to say or how to connect with anyone.

That sounds really overwhelming. It's okay to feel awkward or nervous when meeting new people, especially if you're introverted. It's understandable that you're worried about fitting in, but it's important to remember that everyone feels that way at some point, even in new situations.
Yeah, I get that, but I still feel like I’m gonna be the only one struggling to figure this out. It’s just hard to imagine myself actually making friends when I’m so in my head about it.

It's understandable to feel that way, especially when your mind is racing with worries about the future. Have you thought about what your life might be like in a few months if you take small steps to connect with others, even if it's just one person at a time?

Yeah, I mean, I’ve tried to picture it, but it’s hard to see past the nerves right now. I guess if I could just talk to one person and it goes okay, that might help, but I’m still kinda stuck on how to even start that.

It's okay to feel stuck right now, and it's great that you're open to the idea of taking small steps. Can we try to imagine that scenario where you connect with one person together? What would that look like, and what might help you feel more at ease in that moment?

Honestly, I think just picturing myself walking up to someone and saying hi feels so weird and forced. I’d probably be overthinking every word, but maybe if it’s in a casual setting, like a class or club, it’d feel less scary if I had something specific to talk about, you know?
It sounds like having a shared interest or activity could help ease some of that pressure. What kind of classes or clubs might you be interested in joining?

I’m not totally sure yet, but I’ve been thinking about maybe a book club or something related to my major since I’d at least have that in common with people. It just feels less intimidating if the conversation can start around something I already kinda know about, you know?

Based on your thoughts about a book club or something related to your major, those could be great options to start with. What do you think would be the first step in finding or joining one of those, and how might we make that feel a little less overwhelming?

I guess the first step would be looking up if there’s a book club or some group tied to my major on the school website or maybe asking around during orientation. It still feels kinda nerve-wracking to actually show up, so maybe just starting by checking online or writing down a couple questions to ask about the group could make it less daunting.

That's a great idea to start with something low-pressure, like checking online or preparing a few questions to ask. What do you think would help you feel more comfortable once you're actually at the event?

I think maybe just reminding myself that everyone there is probably looking to connect over the same interest could help me relax a bit. Also, having a plan to just listen at first, instead of jumping into talking, might make it feel less intense while I get a sense of the group.

therapist: That sounds like a solid plan to ease yourself into the group dynamic by focusing on listening and reminding yourself of shared interests. How about we check in next session to see how that first step of looking online or preparing questions goes?

client: Yeah, that sounds good to me. I’ll try to have an update for you by then, even if it’s just a small step forward.

concern:
Hi I’m 18 m turning 19 in august and I have to make a choice about college. I have been accepted into my 3rd and 4th choice colleges and I now need to decide if I am gonna take another gap year or go to college this fall.

I would like to go to college as soon as possible but I really want to try and get in to my 1st or 2nd choice schools as they are both 80,000$ cheaper then the other 2 and in a better location
I plan to go for aviation/flight management to be a pilot at all schools 

I am worried about staying another year as all my friends are going to college this year and I would really like to move out and live on my own also I fear I might not get accepted next year if I stay

For the cost my parents have set aside enough money to afford the 80,000$ schools but I feel bad making them spend that much when I could try to get into a far cheaper and better school 

The best schools for my program are my 1st and 2nd choice schools the (cheaper ones)

Also I am in Ontario Canada and all the schools are also in Ontario Canada if it matters 

Hope this all made sense all advice is appreciated 
If you have any questions please ask 

Thanks again

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there! It's great to meet you and have you here today. Please feel free to share anything on your mind, and I'll do my best to listen and support you. What's been on your mind lately?
Hey, thanks for meeting with me. I’ve just got a lot of stress about deciding whether to start college this fall at one of my lower-choice schools or take another gap year to try for my top picks.
It sounds like you're caught between two tough options. Can you tell me more about what's making this decision so stressful for you?
Hey, yeah, it’s just really hard to weigh the pros and cons, you know? I’m worried about missing out on starting my life and also about making the wrong choice financially and academically.

That makes sense. It sounds like you're feeling a bit torn between wanting to move forward and wanting to make sure you're making the right choice for yourself. Can you tell me a bit more about what you're hoping to achieve by starting college this fall or taking another gap year?

Hey, yeah, I guess with starting this fall, I just wanna get moving, you know, start living on my own and not feel left behind while everyone else is heading off. But with a gap year, I’m hoping I can get into a better school that’s cheaper and a better fit for what I wanna do long-term.

It's clear that you're considering the long-term impact of this decision, and you're weighing the potential benefits of both options. Can you tell me more about what you think your life might look like if you start college this fall, versus if you take another gap year?

Hey, yeah, if I start college this fall, I see myself finally out on my own, getting into the groove of school and meeting new people, even if it’s not my dream school. But if I take another gap year, I’m worried I’ll just be stuck at home, feeling kinda isolated while I wait to see if I can get into a better place next time.

It sounds like you're balancing the excitement of independence and growth against the uncertainty of potentially missing out on better opportunities. What would it take for you to feel confident in your decision, regardless of which path you choose?

Hey, I think to feel confident, I’d need to know I’m not wasting time or money, you know, like I’m making a choice that won’t leave me with regrets down the road. Maybe some reassurance that either way, I’m still moving toward my goals, whether it’s starting now or waiting for a better shot.

That desire for reassurance makes a lot of sense, and it’s great that you’re thinking about your long-term goals. It sounds like you want to make sure that whichever path you choose, you’ll still be moving forward in a way that aligns with your values and aspirations. What aspects of your goals do you think are most important to keep in mind when considering these options?

Hey, I think the most important parts of my goals are getting into a solid aviation program that’ll set me up to be a pilot, and also not putting too much financial stress on my family. Like, I wanna make sure I’m in a good spot career-wise without feeling guilty about the cost or like I settled for less than I could’ve aimed for.

Based on what you said, possible options could include starting college this fall to secure a stable career path and avoid further financial strain, or taking another gap year to explore better aviation programs that might offer more financial stability. What do you think might work best for you, and how could we build a plan around that choice?

Hey, I’m kinda torn, but I think starting college this fall might be the safer bet to just get moving on my career path and not stall any longer. Can we maybe talk through how to make the most of a program that’s not my top pick, and figure out ways to still aim for my dream goals while I’m there?

Hey, I’m glad we’re narrowing it down to starting this fall, even if it’s not the ideal scenario. Could we also brainstorm some backup ideas in case I start feeling like I’m missing out on a better program later on?
Hey, I’m really appreciative of us mapping this out together. Could we also chat about how to handle any doubts or second-guessing that might pop up once I’m in the program?

concern:
Hey all! I saw that people can help. So I’m going to try this too!

I am 24 and still in college. I started in 2016 and took some time off to battle depression. Although it was tough, I won eventually. I decided to go back in 2021 and I have been doing well until now. I find myself questioning the reason I’m here all the time. I don’t know what my ‘Why’ or my true purpose is. I don’t care about being my age in college because how others view me doesn’t matter. I believe that I will finish, I think? If I were not in college, I don’t know what I would be doing with myself but working at a soul sucking job. I am having trouble matching actions with my words and thoughts. I haven’t been studying consistently and I sometimes avoid classes. I am on academic probation again and I just don’t understand why I continue to self sabotage when I claim that I am confident and want to be a college graduate. 

I even try to better myself with reading self-help books, talking to my support system, and be more outgoing on campus like joining clubs and going to parties. Parties are played out to me and the clubs are going okay. Atomic habits, reinventing the habit wheel, and meditation have all helped me in short bursts, but I still am having trouble getting my sh*t together. I am starting to feel hopeless. I don’t want to feel hopeless ever again. Last time I felt that way I was deeply depressed. I want to be better than this. How can fight against my negative emotions? How can be more consistent with the things that will better myself? How can I win the war against my mind and body? Any suggestions please?

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! I'm so glad you've decided to share your thoughts and concerns with me today. Please know that this is a safe space, and I'm here to listen and offer support. What would you like to talk about?
Hey, thanks for being here. I’m just really struggling with figuring out why I’m even in college and how to stop sabotaging myself when I know I want to graduate.

I can see that this is a really tough situation for you, and I'm glad you're here to talk about it. It sounds like there are a lot of conflicting feelings going on, and it's okay to feel that way. Can you tell me more about what's been going on that makes you feel like you're sabotaging yourself?
Hey, yeah, it’s just like I keep getting in my own way, you know? Like, I’ll say I’m gonna study or go to class, but then I just don’t, and I end up feeling worse about myself for it.

I can understand how frustrating that must be, especially when you know you want to graduate and make progress. It sounds like there might be a part of you that's struggling with self-doubt or fear of failure, which could be contributing to these feelings of sabotage. Can you tell me more about what goes through your mind when you decide not to study or attend class, even though you know it's important?

Hey, honestly, when I decide not to study or go to class, it’s like this heavy feeling just takes over, and I think, ‘What’s the point?’ or ‘I’m just gonna mess up anyway.’ It’s weird because I know I want this degree, but in the moment, I just feel stuck and end up doing nothing.

That's really brave of you to share that, and it sounds like those negative thoughts can be pretty powerful. What would your life look like in a year if you could overcome that feeling of being stuck and start making progress towards your degree?

Hey, if I could get past this stuck feeling, I think in a year I’d be closer to graduating, maybe even feeling proud of myself for sticking with it. I’d probably have more confidence, like I’m actually building a future I want, you know? How do I even start getting there when I keep falling into the same patterns, though? I just feel like I’m spinning my wheels sometimes.

It's clear that you're aware of the importance of making progress towards your degree, and that's a good starting point. Perhaps we can explore the values that are connected to your desire to graduate and how they might help you break out of these patterns. What would you say is most important to you about earning your degree, and how does that align with the person you want to be in a year from now?

Hey, I think the biggest thing about earning my degree is proving to myself I can do it, you know, like showing I didn’t give up even when things got rough. It’s also about becoming someone who’s got their stuff together, someone who can take on bigger challenges in the future, and I really want to be that person a year from now.

It's inspiring to hear how much this degree means to you, and how it's connected to becoming the person you want to be. What would you say is one small step you could take this week to move closer to that vision, even if it feels a bit scary or uncertain?

Hey, I guess one small step could be just setting a specific time to study for like an hour a day, even if I don’t feel like it. I’m kinda worried I’ll just blow it off again, but maybe if I start super small, I can stick with it—what do you think?

It sounds like you're already taking a big step by being honest about your worries and being open to finding a solution. What if you started with just 15 minutes of studying each day, and gradually build up to an hour?

Hey, yeah, starting with just 15 minutes sounds way less intimidating, like I could probably handle that without freaking out. Do you think I should, like, set a reminder or something to make sure I actually do it, or is there a better way to keep myself on track?

That sounds like a great idea! Setting a reminder can help you stay on track, but you might also want to think about other ways to make this a habit. What if you tried studying at the same time every day, or paired it with something you already do regularly?

Hey, I like the idea of studying at the same time every day, maybe right after I grab my morning coffee or something, since I’m already up and moving. Do you think tying it to something I’m already doing could really help it stick, or should I try something else to keep myself accountable?

It sounds like tying your study time to your morning coffee routine could be a great strategy, especially since you’re already up and moving. What do you think about also sharing your plan with a friend or family member to keep yourself accountable, or perhaps tracking your progress in a journal to reflect on your success?

Hey, I think sharing my plan with a friend could be cool, like having someone to check in with might push me to actually follow through. Tracking progress in a journal sounds okay too, but I’m not sure if I’d keep up with it—do you have any tips on making that part easier or more motivating?

That's great to hear that sharing your plan with a friend could work for you! To make journaling more engaging, perhaps you could try jotting down a quick reflection on your progress at the end of each study session, or even use a fun, colorful notebook to make it more enjoyable. How do those ideas sound?

Hey, I think using a colorful notebook could make journaling a bit more fun, and I’m down to try jotting down quick thoughts after studying. Do you think just writing a sentence or two about how it went would be enough, or should I be more detailed to really get something out of it?

Hey, I’m cool with starting small, like just a sentence or two about how the study session went, since that feels doable. What do you think about checking in next time to see if that’s working for me, or if I need to tweak it?

{ "reasoning": "The session has discussed coping strategies and a next-step plan, but no closure invitation occurred. It's beneficial to continue supporting the client in their progress to ensure they implement these strategies effectively.", "determination": "continue" }

Hey, I’m glad we can touch base next time to see how this journaling thing is going. I’m a bit worried I might slack off, so having that check-in feels like a good safety net—does that sound okay to you?

Hey, I’m really glad we’ve got that check-in planned too, it definitely helps ease my mind knowing we’ll revisit this. Is there anything else you think I should keep in mind to stay on track until then?

concern:
Hello,

It's true that this begins with a mistake of mine but my degree supervisors ended up insulting me, saying I had psychological problems, reaching the point Godwin and denying the fact that I had a physical disability.

It's someone I so immensely trusted and was so grateful to. I hoped to work with them in the future and worked more in their subjects where I had the best grades.

These persons are now less rude against me but I feel so bad about this, I am so deeply hurt and I can't focus on my lectures with them anymore without thinking about what happened.

These persons are the one who gave me interest in the degree I'm pursuing and I'm not even feeling good about my own degree anymore, I'me even doubting my career.

I am old for my cohort as I had a lot of issues in the past with my disability and health and these people are the one who gave me a second chance and now it went like this. I don't think I can change to another degree or start over. But it hurts me to continue. I have only these persons in lectures now, and I feel bad spending 20h a week with them and working on their things and so on.

I'm absolutely lost, I don't know what to do. I fear reaching out, I fear telling them how I feel about what happened, I feel like giving up.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today. I’m here to listen without judgment and support you in any way I can—please feel free to share whatever’s on your mind or in your heart.
Thanks for being here. I’m just really struggling with some stuff that happened with my degree supervisors, and it’s got me feeling pretty lost and hurt.

It's okay to feel lost and hurt when something important like your academic journey is affected. I'm here to listen, and I'm curious about what happened with your supervisors that led you to this point.
Yeah, it’s just been really tough because I trusted them so much, and now I’m questioning everything. I don’t even know if I can keep going with my degree when I feel this way.

It sounds like you're feeling really overwhelmed and conflicted right now, and that's completely understandable given how much trust you placed in your supervisors. I'm here to listen and support you in any way I can as we explore what's been happening.

client: Thanks, I appreciate that. I just feel so stuck, like I don’t know how to move forward when every class with them reminds me of the hurt, and I’m not even sure if I want to keep pushing through this degree anymore.

It must be incredibly difficult to continue with your degree when every class brings back painful memories and feelings of betrayal. Have you ever imagined what your life might look like if you did decide to continue with your degree, despite these challenges?

Yeah, I’ve thought about it, but it’s hard to picture anything positive right now when I just feel so weighed down by everything. I guess I worry that even if I push through, I’ll still feel this resentment or like I’m faking my way through something I used to love.

That sounds like a really heavy weight to carry, and it's understandable that you're struggling to see a way forward right now. What might be one small step that could help you feel a bit more in control, even if it doesn't immediately lift the weight?
Honestly, I’m not even sure what that small step could be. I just feel so drained, like even thinking about a next move is too much when I’m stuck in this headspace.

I hear how exhausted you feel, and it's okay to take a moment to breathe and not force yourself into action right now. Would it help to imagine what life might look like if you allowed yourself a little more time to process everything, rather than feeling like you need to decide immediately?

Yeah, I think giving myself a bit more time could maybe help, just to not feel so rushed into figuring it all out. It’s just hard to even know how to start processing when I’m still so caught up in feeling hurt and stuck.

It sounds like you’re beginning to see that there might be some value in taking a step back to process your feelings before making any big decisions. Have you thought about what it might look like to give yourself permission to slow down and focus on your emotional well-being for a while, even if it means putting your degree on hold temporarily?

I mean, I’ve considered slowing down or even taking a break, but I’m scared that if I stop, I might not come back to it at all. It feels like pausing could mean giving up, and I’m already so behind because of everything I’ve been through.
It's natural to feel that fear, especially when you've been through so much. What if pausing isn't about giving up, but about honoring your need to heal before moving forward?
Yeah, I get that idea of pausing to heal, and part of me really wants that space to just breathe. But I’m still worried it’ll feel like I’m throwing away all the hard work I’ve put in, you know?

Your concern about the hard work you've put in is completely valid, and it shows how much this degree means to you. What if pausing could actually help you come back to it with more clarity and strength, rather than feeling like you're losing ground?

I get that, and the idea of coming back stronger sounds nice, but I just can’t shake the fear that I’ll lose momentum or get stuck in that pause forever. It’s like, I’ve fought so hard to even be here, and stopping feels like I’m risking everything I’ve pushed for.

That fear of losing momentum and risking everything you've worked for is really powerful, and it makes sense that you'd feel that way after everything you've been through. What if we reframe the idea of pausing not as a risk, but as a strategic move to protect your investment in yourself and your future?

Honestly, that makes sense on some level, reframing it as protecting what I’ve built, but I still feel this knot in my stomach about stepping back. Like, what if I lose my place or can’t get back into the groove, you know?

It's completely understandable that you'd feel that knot in your stomach, given the hard-won progress you've made. What if we explore how pausing might actually help you preserve your place, rather than risking it?

Yeah, I hear you on exploring how a pause could help me hold onto what I’ve got, and I’m open to thinking about it. It’s just, there’s still this nagging worry in my head that I’ll fall behind or mess up everything I’ve fought for if I step away even for a bit.

Your worries about falling behind or messing things up are totally valid, especially after all you've fought for. What if we reframe the pause as a way to create space for a fresh perspective, so you can come back even more focused and determined?

I get what you’re saying about a pause giving me space for a fresh perspective, and part of me wants to believe it could help me come back stronger. But I’m still stuck on this fear that taking a break might just make me feel more disconnected or lost, you know?

It’s understandable that the fear of feeling disconnected or lost is still lingering, especially when you’ve worked so hard to get to where you are. What if we also think about the pause as a chance to reconnect with yourself, rather than losing your footing?

Yeah, I can see how a pause might be a chance to reconnect with myself, and that sounds kinda nice in theory. But I’m just so scared that stepping away, even with good intentions, might make it harder to face everything when I come back, you know?

It's natural to feel scared about stepping away, especially when you've worked so hard to face everything. What if we reframe this fear as a sign of how much you care about your progress, and use that care to guide your decision?

Yeah, I get that my fear shows how much I care about what I’ve built so far, and that’s a helpful way to look at it. I’m just still torn because I don’t want to lose momentum, but I also don’t know how to keep pushing through when I feel this stuck.

It sounds like you're caught between two powerful feelings: the desire to protect the progress you've made, and the need to give yourself space to recharge. What if we explore ways to pause that still allow you to hold onto your momentum, even if it's just a little?

Yeah, I think exploring ways to pause without totally losing my momentum could be a good middle ground. I’m just not sure what that would even look like, you know, like how do I step back but still keep some kind of connection to what I’m working on?

You've already mentioned a few strategies that could help you pause without losing momentum, like setting aside a specific time each day to reflect on your progress or using a journal to keep track of your thoughts and feelings. What if we also consider other options, like creating a small ritual to mark the beginning and end of your pause, or setting a gentle reminder for yourself to revisit your goals when you're ready?

Yeah, I like the idea of a small ritual or something to kinda frame the pause, make it feel intentional instead of just drifting away. I’m curious, though, how do I even pick what that ritual could be, or make sure a reminder doesn’t just stress me out more?

You're already thinking through this in such a thoughtful way, which is a great sign. Maybe the ritual could be something simple and meaningful to you, like lighting a candle or going for a short walk. As for the reminder, it could be as gentle as a weekly check-in with yourself, where you reflect on how you're feeling and whether you're ready to move forward. What feels most soothing or energizing to you when you imagine these possibilities?

Honestly, I think a short walk could be kinda nice, like just stepping outside for a bit to clear my head and mark that pause. Something about fresh air feels calming, and I guess I’m wondering if I could tie that to reflecting on how I’m doing without it turning into overthinking.

client: Honestly, I’m not even sure what that small step could be. I just feel so drained, like even thinking about a next move is too much when I’m stuck in this headspace.
therapist: I hear how exhausted you feel, and it's okay to take a moment to breathe and not force yourself into action right now. Would it help to imagine what life might look like if you allowed yourself a little more time to process everything, rather than feeling like you need to decide immediately?
client: Yeah, I think giving myself a bit more time could maybe help, just to not feel so rushed into figuring it all out. It’s just hard to even know how to start processing when I’m still so caught up in feeling hurt and stuck.
therapist: It sounds like you’re beginning to see that there might be some value in taking a step back to process your feelings before making any big decisions. Have you thought about what it might look like to give yourself permission to slow down and focus on your emotional well-being for a while, even if it means putting your degree on hold temporarily?
client: I mean, I’ve considered slowing down or even taking a break, but I’m scared that if I stop, I might not come back to it at all. It feels like pausing could mean giving up, and I’m already so behind because of everything I’ve been through.
therapist: It's natural to feel that fear, especially when you've been through so much. What if pausing isn't about giving up, but about honoring your need to heal before moving forward?
client: Yeah, I get that idea of pausing to heal, and part of me really wants that space to just breathe. But I’m still worried it’ll feel like I’m throwing away all the hard work I’ve put in, you know?
therapist: Your concern about the hard work you've put in is completely valid, and it shows how much this degree means to you. What if pausing could actually help you come back to it with more clarity and strength, rather than feeling like you're losing ground?
client: I get that, and the idea of coming back stronger sounds nice, but I just can’t shake the fear that I’ll lose momentum or get stuck in that pause forever. It’s like, I’ve fought so hard to even be here, and stopping feels like I’m risking everything I’ve pushed for.
therapist: That fear of losing momentum and risking everything you've worked for is really powerful, and it makes sense that you'd feel that way after everything you've been through. What if we reframe the idea of pausing not as a risk, but as a strategic move to protect your investment in yourself and your future?
client: Honestly, that makes sense on some level, reframing it as protecting what I’ve built, but I still feel this knot in my stomach about stepping back. Like, what if I lose my place or can’t get back into the groove, you know?
therapist: It's completely understandable that you'd feel that knot in your stomach, given the hard-won progress you've made. What if we explore how pausing might actually help you preserve your place, rather than risking it?
client: Yeah, I hear you on exploring how a pause could help me hold onto what I’ve got, and I’m open to thinking about it. It’s just, there’s still this nagging worry in my head that I’ll fall behind or mess up everything I’ve fought for if I step away even for a bit.
therapist: Your worries about falling behind or messing things up are totally valid, especially after all you've fought for. What if we reframe the pause as a way to create space for a fresh perspective, so you can come back even more focused and determined?
client: I get what you’re saying about a pause giving me space for a fresh perspective, and part of me wants to believe it could help me come back stronger. But I’m still stuck on this fear that taking a break might just make me feel more disconnected or lost, you know?
therapist: It’s understandable that the fear of feeling disconnected or lost is still lingering, especially when you’ve worked so hard to get to where you are. What if we also think about the pause as a chance to reconnect with yourself, rather than losing your footing?
client: Yeah, I can see how a pause might be a chance to reconnect with myself, and that sounds kinda nice in theory. But I’m just so scared that stepping away, even with good intentions, might make it harder to face everything when I come back, you know?
therapist: It's natural to feel scared about stepping away, especially when you've worked so hard to face everything. What if we reframe this fear as a sign of how much you care about your progress, and use that care to guide your decision?
client: Yeah, I get that my fear shows how much I care about what I’ve built so far, and that’s a helpful way to look at it. I’m just still torn because I don’t want to lose momentum, but I also don’t know how to keep pushing through when I feel this stuck.
therapist: It sounds like you're caught between two powerful feelings: the desire to protect the progress you've made, and the need to give yourself space to recharge. What if we explore ways to pause that still allow you to hold onto your momentum, even if it's just a little?
client: Yeah, I think exploring ways to pause without totally losing my momentum could be a good middle ground. I’m just not sure what that would even look like, you know, like how do I step back but still keep some kind of connection to what I’m working on?
therapist: You've already mentioned a few strategies that could help you pause without losing momentum, like setting aside a specific time each day to reflect on your progress or using a journal to keep track of your thoughts and feelings. What if we also consider other options, like creating a small ritual to mark the beginning and end of your pause, or setting a gentle reminder for yourself to revisit your goals when you're ready?
client: Yeah, I like the idea of a small ritual or something to kinda frame the pause, make it feel intentional instead of just drifting away. I’m curious, though, how do I even pick what that ritual could be, or make sure a reminder doesn’t just stress me out more?
therapist: You're already thinking through this in such a thoughtful way, which is a great sign. Maybe the ritual could be something simple and meaningful to you, like lighting a candle or going for a short walk. As for the reminder, it could be as gentle as a weekly check-in with yourself, where you reflect on how you're feeling and whether you're ready to move forward. What feels most soothing or energizing to you when you imagine these possibilities?
client: Honestly, I think a short walk could be kinda nice, like just stepping outside for a bit to clear my head and mark that pause. Something about fresh air feels calming, and I guess I’m wondering if I could tie that to reflecting on how I’m doing without it turning into overthinking.

concern:
So this is a long story and I'm currently in a bit of a unique situation because of which there's no one irl who i can ask for reliable advice so as much as reddit is really not the place to be asking for advice on life changing decisions i've got no other options and here we go.

**TDLR:  was a good student, went to horrible uni and tried to survive. now burnt out, looking to transfer but bc of horrid uni application is fucked. thinking of dropping out want to know abt how likelihood of job opportunities for foreign drop-outs. read passages marked \* for a longer summary**

**\*** The story basically goes that, I am an Indian citizen, but i've lived my whole life abroad so i know as much about India as ur next door neighbour + like 5%, okay. At the end of high school, I blindly trusted my parents' suggestion and got into and started attending a top 10 indian uni which has now become the single worst decision i've ever made in my entire life.

As it turned out, my uni is 100% fucked up. I could go on abt it for days but we don't have time to give a short summary of the vibes: extreme mismanagement of an institution, horrible facilities/classrooms, no sense of academic integrity, poor teaching, no sort of proper functioning basic 'services' like student welfare or career counselors provided, straight up illegal shit like holding classes in a construction site, the fact that you DON'T HAVE WIFI NOR DOES MOBILE DATA WORK BC NETWORK IS SO BAD on campus, the list goes on.

Getting back to my situation, my first year was online and EVERYONE cheated on EVERYTHING but I didn't know how to so I didn't and ended up with the lower side of decent kinda grades (mainly bc most of the syllabus was geared to start off from what was taught in the Indian curriculum that I obv didn't study and so there were large gaps in my knowledge that I wasn't even aware of). For detail, I averaged a 8.33/10 CGPA.

In my 2nd year, we went irl, I got my shit together, worked super hard but bc there is literally no sense of fair grading and cheating is rampant at my uni, so my efforts have only given mediocre results. (I got a 8.73/10 GPA in that sem, now averaging 8.46). This added with overwork (my uni is 6 days a week, 1 month holiday for summer, 1 week for winter, sometimes we do 7 days a week working and the semesters are back-to-back i.e. after the last day of sem 3, the next day is sem 4), I am super burned out rn with v low morale.

**\*** I've decided to transfer but I have a v weak application, I only focused on studying and I do computer science so I need projects/stuff to appear as a suitable candidate. I am generally quiet and mainly focused on self-learning bc of my low-quality classes so my letter of recommendations is also super weak. Ofc i do have potential, i am smart, i am hard working, i am capable. But my situation for the past 2 years has been HORRENDOUS and unfortunately no uni is going to understand that. After all i go to a top10 uni, hundreds of fully capable candidates graduate from there every year and i am the only one making excuses.

**\*** My only other option is to drop out. But my main priority is to leave India bc I cannot live here on my own like i don't know the language or the customs, etc and unlike every other country i've lived in you can't just google get straight forward answers for things in India which is the only survival method i've learnt. Which basically means if I drop out, I would have to learn computer science on my own and get a job abroad and i've never heard of anyone do that or the prospects of that path so I am super unsure.

This post has been an absolute mess but if anyone could help i'd appreciate it so so much.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome! I'm so glad you're here. I'm here to listen and support you, and I encourage you to share whatever's on your mind or heart. Take your time, and know that everything we discuss is confidential and nonjudgmental.
Hey, thanks for having me. I’m just really overwhelmed with everything going on, and I’m not even sure where to start with all the mess in my head.
I'm really glad you're here, and it sounds like you're feeling quite overwhelmed. Would it be helpful to start by just sharing what's been on your mind lately?
Yeah, I think that’d be good. I’ve just been stuck in this spiral of stress about my uni situation and future, and I’m kinda lost on what to do next.

It sounds like you're feeling really overwhelmed with your current situation, and that's totally understandable. It's okay to feel lost right now, and I'm here to help you navigate those feelings. Can you tell me more about what's been going on with your uni situation and future that's been causing you so much stress?
Hey, yeah, it’s just been a lot. My uni experience has been a complete disaster, and it’s left me feeling burned out and clueless about where I’m headed, you know?

It sounds like you've been going through a really tough time with your university experience, and it's completely understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and unsure of your direction. I'm here to listen and support you as you work through these feelings, and I'm curious to hear more about what's been contributing to this sense of burnout and uncertainty for you.

Hey, yeah, thanks for being here to listen. It’s just been a mix of awful conditions at uni and feeling like my hard work isn’t getting me anywhere, which has totally drained me and made me question everything about my path forward.

That sounds like a really difficult experience to navigate, and it's understandable that you're feeling drained and uncertain about your path forward. I'm curious, what would it look like for you to feel like your hard work is paying off and your path forward is clear?

Hey, honestly, I think it would feel like finally being in an environment where my efforts are recognized and I’m actually learning and growing, you know? Like, having a clear idea of steps I can take that lead somewhere, instead of just spinning my wheels in a messed-up system.

That sounds like a really important goal for you, and it's completely understandable that you want to feel like your efforts are recognized and that you're learning and growing. What steps do you think you could take to start creating that environment for yourself?

Hey, I’m not really sure, to be honest, because I feel so stuck right now. I’ve been thinking about transferring to a better uni or even dropping out, but I’m scared neither option will work out and I’ll just end up in a worse spot.

That fear is completely understandable, and it's important to weigh the potential risks and benefits of each option. What would it mean for you to take a small step toward exploring either transferring or taking a break, without fully committing to either option just yet?

Hey, I guess taking a small step would mean like, maybe researching some unis abroad or looking into what kind of resources or support I could get if I took a break, you know? I’m just kinda nervous about even starting that process because I don’t wanna get my hopes up and then have it all fall apart again.

That's a valid concern, and it's okay to feel nervous about taking that first step. One small action you could consider is setting aside a specific time this week to look into one university abroad, just to get a sense of what the process might involve. Alternatively, you could start by reaching out to one person in your support network, whether that's a family member or a friend, to talk through your thoughts and feelings. Which of these options feels like the smallest step you could take right now?

Hey, I think starting with just looking into one university abroad feels a bit more doable right now, you know? I’m kinda hesitant to talk to family or friends yet because I don’t wanna deal with their opinions until I have a clearer idea of what I even want.

That's a great choice, and it sounds like a manageable first step. If you're comfortable sharing, could you tell me a bit more about what aspects of this university you're interested in researching? And if you don't mind me asking, how would you like to structure your research - perhaps setting aside a specific time or day this week to focus on this?

Hey, I think I’d wanna start by just checking out their computer science program, like what kind of courses they offer and if they have any specific requirements for international transfers, you know? And maybe setting aside like an hour or two this weekend to dig into their website and see what’s what would work for me, since I’ve got a bit of downtime then.

That sounds like a solid plan, and it's good that you're thinking about how to structure your research. How would you like to handle any potential challenges that might come up during your research, like feeling overwhelmed or not finding the information you need?

Hey, I guess if I start feeling overwhelmed, I could just take a break and come back to it later, or maybe jot down what’s stressing me out to sort through it, you know? And if I can’t find the info I need, I might try emailing their admissions office or looking for forums where other students might’ve shared their experiences.

Hey, I appreciate having a plan for those potential hiccups, it makes me feel a bit more in control. So, do you think checking in next session about how this research went would be helpful, just to keep me on track?

Hey, I’m glad we’ve got this plan in place too, it really helps ease my mind a bit. Yeah, checking in next session sounds like a good idea to keep me accountable and talk through anything that comes up.
Hey, I'm really glad we’ve got this set up, and I feel a bit more confident moving forward. Thanks for helping me think through this stuff—do you have any other quick tips before we wrap up?

concern: What experiences did you realize you needed that you needed to develop bfr going to college.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm so glad you're here to share your thoughts and concerns. Please feel free to open up about whatever's on your mind, and I'll be here to listen and support you.
Hey, thanks for having me. I’ve been thinking a lot about how I wish I’d figured some things out before starting college, you know, just to feel more prepared for everything.
It sounds like you've been reflecting on how things might have gone differently if you'd had more time to prepare. Can you tell me a bit more about what's been on your mind lately?
Yeah, I’ve just been mulling over how I could’ve been better equipped for the whole college experience. It’s like I jumped in without really knowing what I needed to handle the challenges.

It's understandable to feel that way, especially when adjusting to such a significant life change. What do you think would have made you feel more prepared, if you could go back and do things differently?

Honestly, I think I would’ve liked to have a better grip on managing my time and stress before diving into college. It’s just been overwhelming trying to figure that out while everything else is happening, you know?

You seem to feel like you’ve been juggling a lot of new challenges all at once, and it sounds like time and stress management have been particularly tough to balance. What does a typical day look like for you right now, and how do you usually handle stress when it feels overwhelming?

Yeah, my days are kinda all over the place—between classes, assignments, and trying to keep up with friends, I’m just running around a lot. When stress hits hard, I usually just push through or distract myself with my phone, but I know that’s not really working.

It's clear that you've been trying to find ways to manage everything, but it sounds like you might be feeling a bit stuck in the way you're handling stress. Have you ever considered any other strategies that could help you balance everything more effectively?

Yeah, I’ve thought about trying stuff like making a schedule or maybe even some mindfulness stuff, but I’m not really sure where to start with it. It just feels like one more thing to add to my plate, you know?

I hear you—trying to manage everything and then also figure out new strategies can definitely feel like a lot. If we could imagine a version of you who had mastered time and stress management, what would your days look like then? How would that version of you handle the same situations you're facing now?

Man, if I had that all figured out, I think my days would feel way more in control—like I’d actually know what I’m doing hour by hour without this constant scramble. That version of me would probably take a step back when stress hits, maybe breathe for a sec or prioritize stuff instead of just freaking out or zoning out.

It sounds like that version of you has some really effective strategies for managing stress and time. You mentioned taking a step back, breathing, and prioritizing tasks—how do you think those strategies might help you feel more in control? What steps could you take to start integrating some of these ideas into your current routine?

Yeah, I think taking a step back and breathing would help me slow down the chaos in my head, like just giving myself a moment to think straight instead of spiraling. As for prioritizing, it’d probably stop me from feeling so overwhelmed if I could just focus on one thing at a time, and starting small with a simple to-do list or setting aside five minutes to chill could be doable, I guess. What do you think—should I just pick one of those to try first, or is there a better way to ease into it?

It sounds like you're onto something with starting small—maybe try one strategy first and see how it feels? What do you think would be the easiest to try right now, and what might make it feel doable?

Honestly, I think starting with just taking a few minutes to breathe when I’m feeling overwhelmed might be the easiest to kick off with. It doesn’t require much planning, and I can do it pretty much anywhere, so maybe setting a reminder on my phone to pause once or twice a day could help make it stick.
That sounds like a great starting point, and setting reminders on your phone could be a helpful way to make it a habit. What do you think might make those reminders feel more effective for you?

I guess making the reminders kinda specific, like setting them for times I know I’m usually stressed—like right after a big class or when I’m starting to study. Maybe even adding a little note in the reminder, like “just breathe for a sec,” could nudge me to actually do it instead of ignoring it.
That’s a solid idea to tailor the reminders to specific stressful moments. Do you think having a particular spot or routine, like stepping outside for a breather, could help reinforce it even more?

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome! I'm so glad you're here. Please feel free to share anything on your mind—I'm here to listen and support you.
Thanks for being here. I’m just really stressed about this grade from a couple years back and how it might mess up my chances for grad school.

It's understandable to feel stressed about something from a couple of years ago affecting your future plans. Can you tell me a bit more about what happened with that grade and how it's making you feel now?

Yeah, I’m just really worried that this one bad mark is going to hold me back from getting into a good program. It’s been on my mind a lot lately, like I can’t shake the feeling that it’s gonna ruin everything.

So, like, do you think grad schools are gonna look at this and just toss my application out right away? I mean, I’ve worked hard since then, but I’m scared it’s still gonna be a dealbreaker.

It's understandable to feel anxious about a past grade potentially impacting your future. You're clearly very dedicated to your education, and it's important to remember that grad schools consider a wide range of factors beyond just grades. Your hard work since then is definitely worth highlighting, but I'd love to hear more about how this specific grade is weighing on you.

Thanks for saying that, it helps to hear that they look at more than just grades. I guess I’m just stuck on this one mark because it feels like a big red flag on my transcript, and I’m scared it’ll overshadow everything else I’ve done. 

So, like, do you think I should try to retake the class or do something to fix it, even if I don’t technically need to? I just don’t want to leave any doubts for the admissions people.
